Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 07:09PM EnglishMajor wrote: I think the stress question hasn't been conclusively settled, but it probably can't help... Statistically, I believe that most breast cancer is sporadic (vs. inheirited). At a basic level. cancer signifies cells gone wild.  Before you had cancer, cell division proceeded in an orderly fashion. What made our cells start spreading like kudzu? It could be a combination of environmental and other factors. (For example, in my case, not having kids resulted in decades of unopposed estrogen which probably wasn't good. My mom died of breast cancer in her 50s--I don't have the BRCA gene, but maybe I just have one they haven't decoded yet.) I was in a stressful job and I don't think that helped either.   Here's what NCI says:  The genetic material (DNA) of a cell can become damaged or changed, producing mutations that affect normal cell growth and division. When this happens, cells do not die when they should and new cells form when the body does not need them. http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/stress Can stress increase a person's risk of developing cancer? Studies done over the past 30 years that examined the relationship between psychological factors, including stress, and cancer risk have produced conflicting results. Although the results of some studies have indicated a link between various psychological factors and an increased risk of developing cancer, a direct cause-and-effect relationship has not been proven (3, 4). Some studies have indicated an indirect relationship between stress and certain types of virus-related tumors. Evidence from both animal and human studies suggests that chronic stress weakens a person's immune system, which in turn may affect the incidence of virus-associated cancers, such as Kaposi sarcoma and some lymphomas (5). More recent research with animal models (animals with a disease that is similar to or the same as a disease in humans) suggests that the body's neuroendocrine response (release of hormones into the blood in response to stimulation of the nervous system) can directly alter important processes in cells that help protect against the formation of cancer, such as DNA repair and the regulation of cell growth (6).

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2012 08:54AM - edited Apr 7, 2012 08:55AM by EnglishMajor I thought Musa Mayer at www.bcmets.org made some good points: She writes:   ....the guideline about follow-up after early breast cancer has been an ASCO recommendation for 13 years, as you can see from looking here at this 2006 update of the 1999 guideline:  So ASCO issuing this recommendation is nothing new, and still about a third of oncologists use these tests for follow-up anyway. Neither is the recommendation for discontinuation of chemotherapy after three failed regimens in bedridden metastatic cancer patients anything new. This has been a part of the NCCN guidelines for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer for as long as I can remember. The National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines are the most widely used and respected guidelines for cancer issued annually. Look at page BINV-19 of the Breast Cancer Clinical Practice Guidelines, which you can find on the NCCN website at www.nccn.org You have to register to get access, which is why I can't give you the exact webpage for the guidelines. So, these guidelines have been in place for many years, and yet treatment options for women with mets continue to increase, and proactive, informed, insured women like yourselves are able to gain access to as many lines of treatment as you feel are right for you. From the widespread negative reaction to these recommendations, I'm quite confident that's not going to change any time soon. I think the strongest motivation behind this recommendation is the wish to spare patients near death the added pain and suffering from chemotherapy drugs administered in the week or two prior to death, and allow a more peaceful passing. If chemo at the end of life was a rare occurrence, that would be one thing, but studies that indicate it happens 20-50% of the time to cancer patients. To me, that is horrifying, and I too would like to believe there might be a way to avoid that added misery, a way easier than having the difficult conversations about dying so many avoid at all costs. But I think that thi recommendations will simply be ignored, as the existing guidelines have been, because of the powerful reactions people have to the thought that their choices for treatment might be restricted, and that their sense of hope would be taken away. Here's what haunts me, though. When they studied metastatic non-small cell lung cancer patients on fourth-line chemotherapy, they found that 0% responded to the chemo, and that it made them die much sooner. As in months sooner. The concern is that this may also be true for other kinds of cancer, that there comes a time when further treatment is futile and toxic, and that patients may live longer without chemotherapy after it stops working when tried repeatedly, leaving them precious time with their families, but we don't know that. It's not the patients like you who are most likely to have this happen to them. It's the many, many, many people who don't ever talk about this with their doctors or with their families, who don't understand or don't have explained their treatment options, the risks, benefits and chances of response, the patients whose families pressure them to keep on receiving treatment. And it's the doctors who are uncomfortable with any discussion of dying, who feel a sense of personal failure, who can't stop treating patients, who ignore their responsibility as healers to help their patients through this final transition... ...I don't know what the answer is. Guidelines are only that, and many if not most doctors and patients will make other choices, rightly or wrongly. But I don't think they are anything to be feared. To me, it is never an either/or...we always need to weigh both the evidence AND what patients want. I just always want decisions to be as informed as possible. Musa

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2010 08:05AM EnglishMajor wrote:  Becky (rkt) has shared her experience (having a mastectomy) on this board. She goest to MDA and her oncologist has published several articles on the topic. AnnaNYC compiled the crib sheet below in a previous thread.  I am 45 and presented with a low volume of mets last July, discovered when doing bone scan in anticipation of mastectomy, which was then postponed. Have been on tamoxifen/zoladex/zometa since then and things are pretty much stable.  My doctor notes that their are currently no prospective studies but retrosprective (looking back thru charts, i.e., not the strongest evidence) data does suggest some benefit. Although I hope my cancer wlll be under control for a long, long time, there is no guarantee that it will not grow (ulcerate, etc.). I know that having the surgery offers no guarantee I will do better. But I have a fairly large tumor and I would just from a psychological viewpoint like to get it out of me. (I have to agree with Renee on that.) I will have surgery in a couple weeks. They won't remove any nodes nor will I have reconstruction which should make recovery less complicated.I won't know til after the surgery if radiation is needed. I am in pretty good shape. My doctor stressed that  it was my choice.  Good luck!  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16614878Babiera Babiera GV, et al. Effect of primary tumor extirpation in breast cancer patients who present with stage IV disease and an intact primary tumor.  Annals of Surgical Oncology 2006;13:776-782. M.D. Anderson, Houston, TX -- All (224) breast cancer patients treated at M.D. Anderson between 1997 and 2002 who presented with stage IV disease and an intact primary tumor. CONCLUSIONS: Removal of the intact primary tumor for breast cancer patients with synchronous stage IV disease is associated with improvement in metastatic progression-free survival. Prospective studies are needed to validate these findings. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17522944 Gnerlich J, et al. Surgical removal of the primary tumor increases overall survival in patients with metastatic breast cancer: analysis of the 1988-2003 SEER data.  Annals of Surgical Oncology 2007;14:2187-2194. A retrospective, population-based cohort study by using the 1988-2003 Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program data: 9734 SEER patients with stage IV breast cancer. CONCLUSIONS: Extirpation of the primary breast tumor in patients with stage IV disease was associated with a marked reduction in risk of dying after controlling for variables associated with survival. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/p ubmed/17687611 Fields RC, et al. Surgical resection of the primary tumor is associated with increased long-term survival in patients with stage IV breast cancer after controlling for site of metastasis.  Annals of Surgical Oncology 2007;14:3345-3351. Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO - 409 patients with stage IV breast cancer treated from 1996 to 2005. CONCLUSIONS: Surgical excision of the primary breast tumor was associated with significantly longer survival in this cohort of stage IV breast cancer patients, even after controlling for other factors associated with survival. Randomized clinical trials are needed to validate these findings. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18438108 Blanchard DK, et al. Association of surgery with improved survival in stage IV breast cancer patients. Annals of Surgery 2008;247:732-738. Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX - 807 women with stage IV disease at presentation. CONCLUSION: Patients with stage IV breast cancer who had definitive surgical treatment of their primary tumors had more favorable disease characteristics. However, after adjustment for these characteristics, surgical treatment remained an independent factor associated with improved survival. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18357493 Rao R, et al. Timing of surgical intervention for the intact primary in stage IV breast cancer patients. Annals of Surgical Oncology 2008;15:1696-702. University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas - review of all breast cancer patients between 1997 and 2002 presenting with an intact tumor and synchronous metastatic disease. Patients who underwent surgery in the 3-8.9 month or later period had improved metastatic progression-free survival. CONCLUSIONS: Surgical extirpation of the primary tumor in patients with synchronous stage IV disease is associated with improved metastatic PFS when performed more than 3 months after diagnosis. Resection should be planned with the intent of obtaining negative margins. HOWEVER, this paper from Brigham and Women's in Boston does NOT see any real benefit: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18581232 Bafford AC et al. Breast surgery in stage IV breast cancer: impact of staging and patient selection on overall survival. Breast Cancer Research and Treatment 2009;115:7-12 Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston - Review of prospectively maintained database of 147 women who presented with stage IV breast cancer between 1998 and 2005. CONCLUSIONS: Breast surgery is associated with improved survival in stage IV breast cancer. However, in our experience, this benefit is only realized among patients operated on before diagnosis of metastatic disease and is likely a consequence of stage migration bias. While some women may warrant palliative surgery to the breast, it is unclear that such surgery otherwise improves clinical outcomes. The possible biases in these retrospective studies are summed up well in this editorial (the link should take you to the whole article): http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2077920/?tool=pubmed Khan SA. Primary Tumor Resection in Stage IV Breast Cancer: Consistent Benefit, or Consistent Bias? Annals of Surgical Oncolog 2007;14:3285-3287 ...five retrospective studies... present us with consistent evidence that either surgical therapy of the primary tumor has a substantial survival benefit in women with metastatic breast cancer, or there is a strong and consistent selection bias driving the use of surgery in women who have more favorable profiles (i.e., younger age, smaller tumor burden, better access to care). It is also possible that surgery is a surrogate indicator of more aggressive therapy overall, including more aggressive systemic therapy, which translates into better survival. All authors acknowledge the problem of selection bias in the interpretation of these data, and all advocate for a randomized trial to settle this question.

Posts.Content: May 21, 2010 05:25PM EnglishMajor wrote: My scenario is a little bit different, so I don't know that it will have direct application, so here goes... I was diagnosed with breast cancer last fall. Initially I was slated for a mastectomy but then a small volume of bone mets were discovered (meaning I presented with Stage IV). With an advanced cancer, surgery is not the norm, but if you have a low amount and it is in good control there is thought to be some benefit.  I started with Tamoxifen and recently just had a mastectomy. If my cancer were aggressive/immediately life threatening, I would have had to have chemo ASAP. Because it wasn't, I had the luxury of time to do hormonal treatment (which I will stay on as long as it keeps working).  I am small breasted with a big tumor(s). Reconstruction wasn't really an option, but bc of the tumor size, I do think the surgeon had to take more skin.    With Stage IV, it's the least toxic option first (hormonals vs. chemo, if poss). You don't mention your grandma's age or if she has other health issues, but that may also factor in the doctor's thinking. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 06:51AM EnglishMajor wrote: Hi Storm Well, that is certainly a drastic change in plans--I am sorry you had to go thru this ordeal and then have the treatment rug pulled out from under you.  Originally my oncologist suggested I would likely start with taxol and avastin. To the point of telling me about losing my hair and then showing me the infusion room on my way out. This was all a bit premature--but based on her outline, I had a port put in at the same time they did the bone biopsy.  At my second and LAST appointment with her she very casually said "Oh, you'll start with tamoxifen." Me: "So what do I have this port for?"   Her: "Blahblahblahblah...." On the one hand, I was very fortunate I could start with the mildest option first.  And, I have used the port for blood draws and zometa (bone booster infusion). I did not have nearly the preparation ordeal that you did, but I really found this big switch upsetting--I was braced for one thing and then wham! Not doing that. (Altho yes, I am glad I could hold off on chemo.) It is small comfort, but virtually everyone with bone mets will get zometa or xgeva (bone booster) and you do have to have your teeth fixed before you can do those. So your efforts are not in vain, you probably would need to get your teeth fixed very soon.  I don't think my original oconologist understood why this big change (with no warning) from her original plan was so upsetting. I felt she could have given equal time to BOTH treatment possibilities. When I asked her why she NEVER mentioned tamoxifen during our first meeting, she was very patronizing---as tho I was off my nut. My second opinion oncologist confirmed that tamoxifen was an appropriate treatment. I liked her a LOT better than Dr. Debbie Downer, so I switched. If you have the option of getting a second opinion, it can only help. It probably won't change the treatment plan, but maybe you can find a better communicator! Hang in there

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2011 02:30AM EnglishMajor wrote:  My bone mets were dx'd with a bone scan and verified with a bone biopsy. Bone biopsy isn't routine--it depends on the location and other factors. There might be concern with the rib or spot where it is located.  I also had a CT and MRI when I was dx'd stage IV. I did have a PET some months later.  After  a year or so in tx, I had some inconclusive scans (bone, CT and PET). So the dr. sent me for an xray.  After I was stable on antihormonal tx for about six months, I did have a mx. There is thought to be some benefit in some cases. Triple positive cancer is less responsive to antihormonal tx and is often more aggressive. So chemo is often used early on. (I haven't had chemo yet, I am HER2-) http://www.cancer.org/Cancer/BoneMetastasis/OverviewGuide/bone-metastasis-overview-diagnosed  The ACS offers this explanation of imaging tests: Imaging tests to find bone metastases X-rays: X-rays of the bone can show signs that the cancer has spread. X-rays can also find breaks in bones that have been weakened by mets. Bone scan: This test helps show whether a cancer has spread to the bones. A radioactive substance is put into a vein and collects in diseased bone cells throughout in the body. These areas can be seen on the scan and are called "hot spots." Bone scans can often find mets much sooner than normal x-rays. But arthritis, infection, or other bone diseases can also cause hot spots. CT scans: The CT scan uses an x-ray beam to take a series of pictures of the body from many angles. A computer combines the pictures to form a detailed image. If bone scans or x-rays do not show mets, this test can help tell whether the cancer has spread into your bones. MRI scans: Like a CT scan, the MRI shows a cross-sectional picture of the body. But the MRI uses radio waves and strong magnets instead of x-rays. MRI scans are especially useful for looking at the spine and spinal cord. PET scan: PET scans use a radioactive form of sugar that is put into a vein. Cancer cells in the body quickly take in the sugar. A special camera is then used to show where the sugar collects. This test can find groups of cancer cells that are too small to see with other tests. It is also helpful when the doctor thinks the cancer has spread but doesn't know where. Newer machines can combine PET and CT scans to give pictures with more details.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 08:12AM EnglishMajor wrote: Hello Romans* Must echo what the other ladies have said. One doctor I know likes to say: "If cancer is the answer than the tissue is the issue."  Meaning they must have your biopsy results before they can "officially" determine the best treatment. Zoladex is ovarian suppression, meaning it will stop your ovaries from making estrogren. If your cancer is ER/PR postive, estrogen will help it grow. So thus ovarian suppression for premenopaual women and tamoxifen (binds to estrogen receptor so estrogen can't get in there).  If your biopsy were to show you are ER/PR negative, ovarian suppression (Zoladex) wouldn't necessariy be appropriate.  I was first dx'd in first week of  August, didn't start actual treatment till about  mid Sept, (waiting for test results, etc.)   I was definitely on edge during the rollercoaster of those months. Many ladies find Ativan very effective for dealing with the stress, etc. Consider asking your doctor about it. Hang in there, you are on the right track.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 01:05PM EnglishMajor wrote: Hi Susan Whew! You have been on a rollercoaster these past few months. I think you have several things to consider. Your oncologist. From what you have said, the treatment sounds reasonable. But if you don't feel your doctor is listening to you, you may want to consider finding an oncologist you have a better partnership with. (As Dr. Larry Norton says, "If you don't like your doctor, he probably doesn't like you either." ) A new doctor could also serve as a second opinion, which would provide peace of mind.   Your treatment. I also presented with bone mets, but I don't have lobular cancer. Surgery is not standard of care of Stage IV people--but in some instances it is thought to be of benefit. Can you clarify why surgery was recommended off the bat? (Didn't know if it had to do with being lobular or something else.) Can you clarify how you came to have recon right away? (Often it is delayed in case the person needs rads.) The rads issue can be six of one, 1/2 dozen of another. It is  a decision often made in consultation with the radiologist and the oncologist. In terms of tracking---that's a tricky issue. Generally speaking, all tests are considered in aggregate--a rising tumor marker would be considered with scan results and the patient's overall well being. (At every appointment an oncologist will typically ask about your energy level, unexpected weigh loss and any new symptoms, such as shortness of breath or  bone pain that persists for a couple weeks.)  In general, for someone with hormone receptor positive bone-only disease, chemo would be reserved until all the antihormonals had been tried. There are probably 5 other antihormonals. It is likely too soon to determine if the tx is working. In terms of the rash, I suggest asking for a referral to a dermatologist. It will put your mind at ease. Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2013 04:19PM EnglishMajor wrote: Hi Mahorgo I was a denovo presentation with a low volume of bone mets four years ago at age 43. I don't have sternal mets tho. I started on tamoxifen and after being stable for a year on it, a unilateral mx was suggested. I had that and then radiation because I had a close margin. Tamoxifen failed after two years so I switched to femara and have been stable on that for two years. Because I was premenopausal, I got a monthly Zoladex ovarian suppression shot while on Tamoxifen. When I started Femera, an oopertectomy was suggested and I had that. Denovo Stage 4 presentations are in the minority. Most people arrived here after being treated for early stage breast cancer. I believe 6 to 10 percent of those with metastatic breast cancer were metastatic from the start.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2012 06:25PM EnglishMajor wrote: Fact: Sugar doesn't make cancer grow faster. All cells, including cancer cells, depend on blood sugar (glucose) for energy. But giving more sugar to cancer cells doesn't speed their growth. Likewise, depriving cancer cells of sugar doesn't slow their growth. This misconception may be based in part on a misunderstanding of positron emission tomography (PET) scans, which use a small amount of radioactive tracer - typically a form of glucose. All tissues in your body absorb some of this tracer, but tissues that are using more energy - including cancer cells - absorb greater amounts. For this reason, some people have concluded that cancer cells grow faster on sugar. But this isn't true. http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/cancer-causes/CA00085/NSECTIONGROUP=2

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 09:37AM EnglishMajor wrote: POSTED: 3:12 pm EST March 10, 2011 UPDATED: 10:03 pm EST March 10, 2011 BOSTON -- How long is too long to make cancer patients wait for promising new drugs? One local couple is frustrated with the Food and Drug Administration's approval process and is demanding changes. Lorraine Heidke-McCartin and her husband, Phil, recently returned from their sixth trip to Virginia this winter. That's the closest place offering an experimental drug to control her advanced breast cancer, the couple said. "I just had my first CAT scan done the week before last and everything has shrunk or it's gone already," Heidke-McCartin said. In studies, T-DM1, a combination of Herceptin and chemotherapy, has shrunk tumors in 33 percent of women with advanced disease, according to Genentech, the drug maker. It also has few side effects. But the travel, at her own expense, has taken a toll on the 54-year-old Hanson woman. "It doesn't have to do with the treatment itself, but it has to do with what you're putting a stage IV, critically ill, terminally ill person through to get a drug," Heidke-McCartin said. Last summer, doctors told Heidke-McCartin she was a perfect candidate for the drug and would start receiving it in Boston at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in September. "Then I picked up the paper, the FDA pulled the rug out, said Phil McCartin. "It's just baffling to me why the FDA did this." The FDA denied accelerated approval and, according to a spokeswoman, will not comment publicly on the reason. In a statement, drug maker Genetech said the FDA told them the drug did not meet the standard for accelerated approval "because all available treatment choices... had not been exhausted" among those in the study. That infuriates Lorraine's husband. "She and hundreds and hundreds of other women across the country have already exhausted all those other options," McCartin said. Sen. John Kerry fired off a letter to the FDA, writing, "Especially when patients have exhausted existing treatment options, they shouldn't have to face unnecessary obstacles to innovative treatments that are potentially life-saving." "As a general rule, it takes too long to get drugs to people who need them," said Dr. Eric Winer, director of the breast oncology center at Dana-Farber. Winer said the overall drug approval process needs to be accelerated. "One of those ways. potentially, is to issue preliminary approvals, do more definitive studies and recognize they may or may not get final approval," Winer said. Genentech spokeswoman Krysta Pellegrino said, "We are really committed to this medicine." She said potential FDA approval isn't likely until late 2012 or early 2013. After several doses of T-DM1, Lorraine is looking better and feeling better. "They're asking me how I'm doing, and I got very teary, and I said for the first time in I can't tell you how long, I feel like me." Heidke-McCartin said. "I was able to play on the ground with my grandchildren, run around with them. Do those kind of things that I've always dreamed I would be doing at this age."

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 08:06AM EnglishMajor wrote:  I have not been in the same boat, maybe some others will chime in with their thoughts. Would the oncologist recommend seeing a pain management specialist? So many trips to ER would be hard on a younger woman, never mind an 82-year-old. Would it make sense to see a geriartric oncologist? Did your MIL have a bone density test?  Is she taking an aromatase inhibitor? AIs may cause problems for women with osteoporosis. AIs tend to worsen bone loss and increase fracture risk.(A patient prone to falling or someone who has had a broken bone due to osteoporosis probably should not be taking AIs.) Should your MIL be taking appropriate calcium and vitamin D3 supplements?   Oncologists rely on clinical signs to go with test resutlts. As you will know from your prior appointments, they will want to know if your MIL has any new bone pain, how her energy level is and how her appetite is. If any changes, of course, bring this up.  Take care

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 06:00PM EnglishMajor wrote:  Hi Jennifer Wow, you have a lot going on. I think the ladies who have transitioned from work to disability will tell you that there is an ajustment involved... maybe they can advise on their strategies. Losing a parent is very stressful--as is caring for a sick spouse and coping with your own illness.   With so much to deal with, it can be hard to know what to do first. Maybe you can pick one thing--like one room or even one drawer to organize. Have you looked into "Cleaning for a Reason"? There is nothing like the boost of coming back to a clean house--that someone else cleaned.  I don't know if you have a regular church--if you go regularly, it is like a standing appointment--you will likely feel closer to God and your neighbors. My church has several volunteer groups--some cook meals for ill people and their families. There are also teens looking for community service projects.  After my mom died (she was 53) my father went on a retreat for widows/widowers. They were asked to write a letter to the person they lost. It helped my dad. He continued to write the letter for about a year and then he typed it up and gave copies to me and my siblings. Maybe you can find a special  way to remember your mom.  You know that you have all the ladies here for you.Your oncologist also should know all that is going on with you--they are treating the whole person and this is an important part of your life the doctor should know about.  Take care.  Here are some links you might like:  http://www.familycaregiving101.org/top_10/  www.terminalillness.co.uk/ www.hospicenet.org/html/grief_...   www.cleaningforareason.org/mai...

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2014 08:37PM EnglishMajor wrote: Heidihill, I had that same reaction--just cause you have spine mets doesn't mean cancer is gonna take the A-train to your brain...I think something like 20% of those with MBC will have brain mets and it has more to do with subtype. (Was there not an oncologist he could have spoken with, for cryeye?) Emma Keller wrote about her  DCIS (or more accurately reconstruction) in an earlier article:  http://emmagkeller.com/blog/2012/06/my-40-day-breast-cancer-a-handful-of-atypical-cells-one-week-a-double-mastectomy-and-reconstructive-surgery-the-next-its-a-cure-but-its-brutal/ This is  Emma Keller's cached article that launched the current furor.  https://web.archive.org/web/20140109033020/http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jan/08/lisa-adams-tweeting-cancer-ethics As I said previously, neither Keller understands what metastatic breast cancer is. Bill Keller's implication--that people like Lisa Adams (who is in fact getting standard of care)--is clutching at straws shows just how poorly understood this disease is. And comparing a 79 year old man's cancer to that of a 40-something mom is just idiotic. I think if you have been on this board, you've read about people with bad bone pain and pleural effusion. While these are serious--and certainly painful things--they are not--as Emma Keller suggests--signs that someone is on their deathbed.  Keller notes that Adams is constantly tweeting--and indeed, most of it is about cancer related things. Some are how she is feeling at that moment, some are are reflections on cancer, living with cancer, etc.  Keller calls this "Dying out loud." Because she doesn't quite "get" MBC, Keller suggested Adams is spending her final days obsessively tweeting. I don't think that is the case. Adams was in the hospital to get rads for pain relief. If I were in her place, I probably would tweet, if I could, for the company. On the other hand, I just couldn't keep pumping out updates about myself and dropping pearls of wisdom--that is just not me. I like to take time to absorb any news on my own. I am fortunate I really don't have a lot of news to share. It does bother me when I see someone, who I kind of feel overstates their treatment for attention/pity etc. I don't mean Adams. There is one person who posts occasional blog updates and has essentially the same treatment as me Femara and Zometa. (Tho I switched to xgeva.) Ok, as we know Zometa is given as an infusion and usually takes 20-30 minutes and generally doesn't have a lot of SE after the first one. Does this woman miss a single opportunity to post pictures of herself hooked up to an IV? Nope! And, because her non-Stage IV friends aren't that savvy, I am sure they think she is getting chemo, poor thing. That just bugs me as it seems dishonest and insulting to those who ARE having some pretty tough treatments.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2014 12:17AM EnglishMajor wrote: Keller feels that his elderly father-in-law (then 79) had a "better" approach to dealing with cancer: No treatment, just pain relief.  I don't doubt this was a great decision for this man, at that time, with his particular health history.  However, where Keller really drops the ball is mistaking Adams' tx as  grasping at straws and implying that she, as a woman of means, is getting "premium" treatment. You know the special Sloan Kettering back room for loyal customers..... Anyone familiar with MBC could quickly discern Adams' treatment is standard of care--NOT "Heroic Measures" as Keller describes them.  I commend Lisa B. Adams for sharing her story. I frankly would be uncomfortable with that level of sharing, but I respect that we are all different. I also wish Lisa would use her platform  to say something for those who don't have her means. If she finds things difficult, what about those don't have cleaning or childcare help or the financial ability not to work? I don't think she has considered that.  But that is her choice and I respect it.  Lisa's story is a compelling one, but it not the only one and I wish more voices were being heard. Still I am very grateful for what she is doing and I hope it brings new awareness of MBC and its treatment.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 08:06AM EnglishMajor wrote:  I think this was on a previous list, but just in case:  Going through cancer treatments, so many of us end up feeling  financially squeezed because we’ve been pummeled with co-pays. The CancerCare Co-Payment Assistance Foundation is one of the more far- reaching organizations I was able to find to help with the barrage of co-pays that it  can be so hard to stay on top of once you’ve been initiated as a warrior. They will pay between $5,000 and $10,000 a year toward co-pays for patients whose income is up to four times above the national poverty level.   That means if you live alone, and are making no more than $43,320, the Foundation can probably assist you. For families of four, the income cap is $88,200. Your assets are not taken into account, so rest assured you get to keep your car, home and all of your other belongings. To be eligible you must either have private insurance or Medicare.  If by chance you don’t qualify, their outreach staff will try to help you find support elsewhere. And through its affiliation with CancerCare.org, the Foundation will also hook you up with free support services, including counseling, workshops, and support groups – all outlets for dealing with survivors’ and families’ issues tied to ways cancer  touches us. To get more of your questions answered, call, 866-55-COPAY. For a list of drugs covered by CancerCare Foundation’s Copayment program (search by cancer type): www.cancercarecopay.org/covered.html

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2012 10:51PM EnglishMajor wrote: Have you talked to the social worker at the hospital? If you are in the US get in touch with your state's department or aging and or public guardian. In IL, when older people can't take care of themselves because of competency or other issues, the state (public guardian) acts on their behalf or someone else (usually family member) has power of attorney for them. I would start with the hospital---what do they advise? If your mom could be a danger to herself, my suggestion would be to call the police. Hang in there.  If your mom is back in the hospital, do not let her be discharged until a care plan is in place. Insist on whatever tests, etc. Tell the hospital your mom can not care for herself.  Take care.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 02:10PM EnglishMajor wrote: I think it is different for everyone and it the expectation/demands of their jobs. I have been on tamoxifen (two years) and now femara (start of this year) with lupron until about a month ago and Zometa until last fall, now Xgeva. Lupron shots could sometimes leave me kinda queasy--since I was able to work from home sometimes I did. Early on I would sometimes come over with a crushing fatigue (to the point where I needed to sit down while shopping). That didn't last, would not have wanted to deal with that in a meeting or while traveling. First Zometa infusion left me feeling like I got hit by a truck, but as most will attest, first is the worst. Femara hasn't been bad for me, but some do get really bad joint pains. If a job required standing all day, that might be an issue.  I faced something of a similar issue when first dx'd. At first it was thought I was Stage 3 and would have chemo/surgery/rads. I had a big industry  confab coming up--if I could not be there, I needed to arrange coverage. I did--only to learn a week later (thank you, bone scan) I have bone mets and old tx plan was scrapped.  So I ended  up going to the event, but I was in a weird kind of limbo.  My job is generally a desk job. Overall I did not have a problem continuing to work, but I did on occasion need to take a day off or just take it easy. But most days I am ok. It is difficult for all concerned, but until you know your tx and have a little time to see how you do with it, you won't know. From my experience, my advice is don't rush to make a pronouncement--wait until you know what is going on.  While most employers are subject to FMLA, the law may not apply to very small companies. Is your company a three-person operation or your department?

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 11:38AM EnglishMajor wrote: Hello fellow wanderer,  I presented with a low volume of bone mets in 2009 and was metastatic from first diagnosis. I had slight progression after two years but I still have low volume of bone mets. Generally the greater concern is visceral mets (to lung, liver, etc). As my one surgeon put it: no one dies of bone mets (which is not say that they are great or a walk in the park). Just that organ mets are a different kettle of fish. I know someday I will no longer have bone-only disease but this is where I am today.  I have never been NED but I have been stable (nothing got bigger or smaller; disease stayed the same). Stable is just as good (or at least for me). Doctors talk about disease tempo--mine would be slow--hasn't done too much. It was "good" that there was a long time between your first dx and then the mets. As you have some treatment under your belt and the disease seems to be regressing this is a "good" sign. Another factor is how you feel in general--if you feel pretty good, good energy, etc. that is a "good" sign.  I also pressed my oncologist for some kind o f prognosis but she didn't give one. They honestly can't.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 02:44PM EnglishMajor wrote:  yourlife.usatoday.com/health/medical/breastcancer/story/2011-10-19/Women-with-advanced-breast-cancers-feel-left-out-forgotten/50831096/1 Although Kelly Lange has had breast cancer for 16 years, she feels unwelcome at most support Like many women with an advanced form of the disease, Lange says she feels alienated from the larger breast cancer community, and out-of-place at the countless events held each October for Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Most focus on "the cure," she says, with brave women describing how they beat a fearsome disease. Lange doesn't expect to beat breast cancer. There is no cure for breast cancer that has metastasized, or spread to other organs; most patients survive just two to three years. "Metastatic breast cancer patients represent the early-stage breast cancer survivor's biggest fear," says Lange, 48, of Annapolis, Md., whose cancer relapsed five years ago. She says she was recently asked to tell her story to a breast cancer group. "When I got to the part about metastasis, people started squirming." Some groups ask women not to reveal that their disease has spread, says Dian "C.J." Corneliussen-James, 60, who has lived five years with metastatic disease. "That means the people with the worst situation have no support." Resources for women with aggressive or advanced breast cancer Inflammatory Breast Cancer Help and Support Metastatic Breast Cancer Network Metavivo National Breast Cancer Coalition At other events, metastatic patients "hear about women who are surviving and celebrating, but they are women who every day have to summon the strength to overcome fatigue and all the other side-effects," says Karen Neyer, an oncology social worker with the Cancer Support Community. "They're living with cancer and going on with their lives every day." Much of the recent discussion of "pink fatigue," including the backlash against what's become known as "Pinktober" and "pinkwashing," has come from women with metastatic disease. Most October breast cancer events - from fundraisers to walks, runs and relays - are "all full of hope," says Sally Drees, 42, of Des Moines, Iowa. [article continues]

"The breast cancer community had become a place for ‘survivors', not for people living with breast cancer every day of their lives. We were not being seen or heard. We have to learn how to live with the ever-present anxiety of knowing it is a matter of time till the present treatment stops working. We are left trying to explain to friends and family why we are still on chemo. The world likes closure and we have no closure." -Ellen Moskowitz, past president of MBCN (www.mbcn.org) ihatebreastcancer.wordpress.co...

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2011 09:28AM EnglishMajor wrote:  Shevawn: Have you seen the Angel Thread on this site?  Those people did not meet St. Peter after they tripped down the basement steps.  I presented with mets--this is my first breast cancer. I am not cured.  Some people with mets may consider themselves to have a chronic disease. But I would wager many women with mets would disagree.   It is possible to have a LOCAL recurrence. That's not mets. If you have a DISTANT recurrence (lungs, liver, brain, bone) yes, you are in a world of hurt, often quite literally.  Take it from the National Breast Cancer Coalition:  www.breastcancerdeadline2020.o...  What is early detection? We probably think of it as early enough to intervene and save a life. But there are different kinds of breast cancer. For some of them, if they are surgically removed, the breast cancer has been effectively "cured." For others, it can be found really early, yet no known intervention will "cure" it. Complicated? Yes. But the truth about breast cancer is just that.

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 10:31AM EnglishMajor wrote:  I recall that I had a hight proliferation rate but my dr. said it wouldn't guide treament choice. I think some of this info is used more for someone who has an early stage cancer to maybe give an idea of recurrence odds.  I also think you have to look at what's happened to you over the year of your treatment. If your cancer was super aggressive your experience would probably reflect that.   Here's an explanation of how the scoring works. (Sounds like figure skating!) http://www.oncolink.org/types/article.cfm?c=3&s=5&ss=838&id=9588&p=2 Histological Grade Histological grade is reported using the "Bloom Richardson Scale" or "Nottingham Score". It is a combination of nuclear grade, mitotic rate, and tubule formation, which are characteristics of the tumor cells seen under a microscope that predict its aggressiveness. Now, this scoring system is very detailed and usually does not affect treatment decisions, so it is not particularly helpful in the big picture. However, you will see it on the report and may be interested in what it means. In general, high grade tumors are more likely to recur when compared to low grade tumors. * Nuclear Grade: a score is given from 1 to 3, based on the appearance of the nucleus of the cancer cells, with 1 being the closest to normal cells (better), 3 being the most variation (worse). * Mitotic Rate: describes how quickly the cancer cells are multiplying or dividing using a 1 to 3 scale, 1 being the slowest, 3 the most rapid. * Tubule formation: this score represents the percent of cancer cells that are in tubule formation. A score of 1 means greater than 75% of cells are in tubule formation (better), a score of 3 is used when less than 10% of cells are in tubule formation (worse), a score of 2 is in between 10 and 75%. The three scores are then combined for a total score between 3 (1+1+1) and 9 (3+3+3). This score translates to a histological grade. You may see the three values and total score or just the final grade. * Score of 3,4 or 5: Well differentiated or low grade (Grade 1) * Score of 6 or 7: Moderately differentiated or intermediate grade (Grade 2) * Score of 8 or 9: Poorly differentiated or high grade (Grade 3)

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2012 08:55AM EnglishMajor wrote: I have held off on sharing the FB Metavivor message for a couple of reasons. (The campaign is really well done, it's not due to that at all) My FB friends are a weird hybrid of actual friends and family as well as many acquaintances from my job. People who know me well do know I have Stage IV breast cancer. But there are probably a lot of people in the industry I work in who don't and some of them are among my FB friends. I don't mind that they know, I just dread the thought of having to talk about my health with people I don't know well and in some cases hardly at all. Like the Divine Miss M, I seldom post about my own BC on FB The other reason I didn't repost....I have a friend from a prior job--I think her mom had early stage breast cancer. My friend did a 3 day walk and sent constant bulletins, fundraising messages etc. This was shortly after I was diagnosed and I would concede my anti pink sentiment was at an all time high. I did support my friend's walk, but a few weeks later, I sent her a note telling her of my dx and how MBC differs from early stage bc. I wasn't a jerk or self righteous, I just felt like I had to tell her it's a different world. To her credit, my friend has subsequently done fundraisers for Metavivor and posts messages about the importance of research for Stage IV breast cancer. But (and as Pee Wee Herman would say everyone has a big but...) this past October she kind of went to the extreme on MBC FB postings. While very well inentioned, some of the posting had the undertone of "Dear Ignorant Friends I Am Going to Make You Feel Really, Really Bad on Behalf of the 150,000 US People Who Are Ultimately Gonna Die From Breast Cancer..." I feared that my FB support for Metavivor would be perceived as invitation for her to get back on the lecture circuit.....

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 07:54AM EnglishMajor wrote:  Well, I am flattered to be asked. . . 1. I am single with no kids. I don't have pets--I live in an apartment which doesn't allow them. But I am not a pet person--I am allergic to cats (and most dogs). When I was five our neighbor's dog (a chihuahua no less) nipped me and I guess I have always been afraid of dogs. I am the youngest of seven kids--and as you noted, a twin. My mother's family was Jewish but not religious. As a college student, she had some Catholic friends, and on her own, converted to Catholicism. My mom, then an art student from Chicago, was in Mexico sketching/researching when she met my father, a Bostonian in the late 1950s. My father was a WW 2 vet as well as an Atomic Vet (at the Nevada proving grounds when atomic weapons were being tested). After my parents married, they soon started their family. Although I have six siblings, we are all practically the same age, only a few years between oldest and youngest. In my case I have an "Irish triplet," one of my brothers is not quite a year older than me and my twin brother. So there were three of us in the same grade. I was pretty shy growing up. I am close to all my siblings, they are all great people.  My father worked an insurance company--he was a creative guy and probably very bored with his job, but those were the days of  job security and he did work for this company his entire life and it did provide a pension. My parents were both family oriented--they always came to our sporting events, took in an interest in all that we did and we did eat dinner as family virtually every night.  Neither of my parents drove. We did not have a car until I was in 7th or 8th grade and one of my older brothers was driving. We lived in small town in Northern IL--there wasn't a lot of public transportation (a bus which served the neighboring communities). So we did a lot of walking. Airlines hadn't been deregulated when I was growing up in the 1970s. Our family took one trip for my grandparents' anniversary--it was very exciting to get on a plane--but I guess did wonder what it would be like to be the Brady Bunch and go on a car trip. (We also did not have a dishwasher--imagine if Alice was around to do all the chores!) My parents did not let us watch much TV--but we managed to keep up with "Happy Days" and whatever the "cool" shows of the day were on the sly. So far I am sure my family sounds like some offshoot of an Amish sect--no car, no TV, etc. but it wasn't like that. Here's a picture of my famiy back in the day.  My mom was dx'd with inflammatory breast cancer when I was 15 and she died a few weeks after three of us graduated from high school (and an older brother graduated from college). I wish my mom had a board like this because she must have felt very isolated--there were no real resources then--even for people with early stage breast cancer. When I was dx'd with MBC, I thought of my mom and I feared I would have the pain and aggressive disease she did. (I don't, but I didn't realize that at first.) Altho my mom had cancer, my cancer is not considered heriditary--I don't have the BRCA1/2 mutation. (Given that my mom was dx'd when she was 51 and I was dx'd when I was 43, I think there is probably a mutation we just don't know about at this point...) My father, a lifelong smoker, died of bladder cancer in his early 70s.  2. I work full-time. I edit a trade magazine (as distinct from a consumer magazine, a trade magazine is free to "qualified" subscribers in that profession). I can't say I have limitations--just time off to go to appointments. I had surgery and rads and then an ooph, so I took time off for that. I do notice I get tired more easily at times, but overall, I can't say I have restrictions. I don't know what I would do if I wasn't working. Sometimes I think I would like not working but it could just be those are times when I am overdue for a vacation... I have traveled at lot for my job, but usually with friends in the industry. I wouldn't care to travel alone. I do volunteer with MBCN.org, mostly writing related projects.  I do have a lot of nieces and nephews--I would probably go to more soccer games.   3. I have always liked to read. Musa Mayer's book  (now out of print, but my cancer center had it) and Lilly Shockney's book provided excellent overviews. Musa had a blog post (she is now on FB) and BCMets.org   where she suggested people read the Third Concensus on the Medical Treatment of Metastatic Breast Cancer http://annonc.oxfordjournals.org/content/20/11/1771.ful. As a technical writer, I guess I have become accustomed to looking for plain English among mountains of jargon. So I wasn't intimidated by what I didn't understand. I knew somewhere there must be a clear explanation. I did not understand the Third Concensus at first, but after I had "been around" a litte while, I could make sense of it.  People have different learning styles. (I don't have the patience to watch videos, but if that works better for you, there are good ones on YouTube, MBCN, etc.) Also, if you have an unusual subtype (triple negative, triple positive, inflammatory, etc etc) there are some associations and websites spefically dedicated to those treatments, take a look. 4. Hmmmm...not sure there is a typical day. Until last fall, I worked downtown. So I would get up and depending on the time of year/weather, I might go for a walk. Upon returning home, I would get ready for work and then take the train downtown. About a 25-minute train ride. I used to be someone who would read the morning paper, but now I read it online. I also like my coffee in the morning, but just one cup. Work is somewhat cyclical--Mondays are typically busy. Generally I will have two very hectic weeks.  I am not a big TV watcher--but I do get sucked into "Law & Order" reruns and classic shows as seen on MeTV, etc. I am not an outdoorsy person (in terms of camping, etc) but I am a big walker--I loved to walk along the Chicago River and Lake Michigan when I was downtown. I have an affinity for junk--I do stop at garage sales, thrift stores, antique stores--I try to do more looking than buying. My Kindle/iPad are awesome but I still have way too many books just sitting around. After I graduated from college I spent some time working in a book store--my father said this was like hiring an alcoholic to work in a liquor store--I would say that was correct! 5. I am very fortunate, I really don't have any physical complaints. I think for me it is a mental challenge--I can't believe this is happening to me--I can't believe I will always be dealing with this. I think my attitude flucuates--right now I really don't have much going on. As I think everyone does, I get on edge when going for scans.  Thanks for asking. Who will be next???

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2012 07:23PM EnglishMajor wrote: SonnyB, as I noted on the Patch site: Earlier this year, Dartmouth professors published a paper in a reputable medical journal criticizing a Susan G. Komen ad campaign for citing the same statistics mentioned in the above article. As CNN reported: Professors Steven Woloshin and Lisa Schwartz at the Dartmouth Institute for Health Policy and Clinical Practice say the foundation overstated the benefits of the procedure and totally ignored the risks. "The ad implies that mammograms have a huge effect, but the only evidence that they use is the five-year survival rate for breast cancer when caught early is 98% and when it's not, 23%," Woloshin said. "The problem is that in the context of screening survival, statistics are meaningless." "To make an informed decision, you not only have to know the benefits you have to know the harm. And the ad does not say anything about harm, it just gives you this exaggerated benefit statistic," Woloshin said... ...Woloshin and Schwartz write a series that highlights exaggerations, distortions and selective reporting in advertising, news stories and medical journals that are misleading. They say the problem in Komen's case is using survival statistics to determine the benefit of screening. "There is no correlation between changes in survival and changes in how many people die." Woloshin said. "Twenty to 50% of women who get screened every year end up having at least one false alarm over 10 years, and 5-20% actually end up having to have a biopsy to rule out cancer. "The most important harm is overdiagnosis -- screening can find cancers that were never destined to cause harm because it grows so slowly or can go away on its own," he said. "It would never have harmed you, you would never have known about it and you would have lived your whole life and died from something else. These people get treated. They get radiation, chemotherapy, surgery and it's all unnecessary. " Woloshin also says the Komen ad ignores the problems with screening. He says for every life saved by screening two to 10 women are 'overdiagnosed', suffer anxiety and undergo unnecessary radiation, chemotherapy or surgery. He said in the end, it all boils down to this: "You can't make a good decision unless you have the basic facts. It exaggerated the benefit and it ignored the harm." But Komen, the world's largest breast cancer charity, says while mammography isn't perfect, it's still the best detection tool available. "We have long advocated for women to be informed about the benefits and risks of early detection and treatment," said Chandini Portteus, Komen's vice president of research, evaluation and scientific programs. "The numbers are not in question. Early detection allows for early treatment, which gives women the best chance of surviving breast cancer." Since its inception in 1982, the organization -- creator of the "pink ribbon," a symbol of breast cancer awareness and the official symbol of National Breast Cancer Awareness Month -- has invested nearly $2 billion in research. "We've said for years that science has to do better, which is why Komen is putting millions of dollars into research to detect breast cancer before symptoms start -- through biomarkers, for example," said Portteus. "Komen also is funding research to help accurately predict which tumors will spread and which won't. While we invest in getting those answers, we think it's simply irresponsible to effectively discourage women from taking steps to know what's going on with their health." Portteus said Komen encourages women to work with their health care providers to find out what's right for them. But according to Woloshin, a recent survey he and his colleagues conducted showed even doctors mistake improved survival as proof that screening saves lives. "The survival statistics are confusing for doctors, too," he said. "This is a real communication problem that doctors and patients alike face, so whenever you hear about survival statistics in the context of screening, you should ignore them. See the full article here: http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/02/health/komen-mammograms/index.html

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2012 01:08PM EnglishMajor wrote: Three other points to keep in mind: 1. Recurrence statistics are elusive. NCI and SEER database record only incidence, initial treatment and mortality data. What happens in between? We don't know. When asked about this, NCI's media contact responded: "Thank you for your interest in NCI and the SEER Program. The SEER Program recognizes the importance of understanding and capturing disease progression and recurrence. You are correct in saying that SEER records information, including stage, at the time of diagnosis and follows men and women who have been diagnosed with cancer to estimate survival. Mortality vs. Survival: Mortality numbers tell the story more precisely than survival numbers, and screening skews the survival numbers. The more we screen, the more we diagnose and treat women with breast cancers that would not have been a threat to their lives (some DCIS, other slow growing invasive breast cancers, and others that are dormant or regressive); so it looks like survival for early stage breast cancer is 98 percent.  This is only a 5-year survival number—and includes the 20-30 percent of women who will have recurrence and may die of the disease later.  For Stage II and III, one-half to two-thirds will develop metastatic disease within five years and they are included in the 5-year survival statistic.  Women die of metastatic disease, not primary breast cancer. As the National Cancer Institute explains thoroughly on its website: But that is a lifetime risk. Risk increases with age, so the NCI provides a more helpful way of looking at it for women of different ages: Note that NCI statistics are "five-year relative survival": ("The survival statistics presented here are based on relative survival, which measures the survival of the cancer patients in comparison to the general population to estimate the effect of cancer.") http://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/breast.html#survival

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 12:33PM EnglishMajor wrote:  http://curetoday.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/blog.showIndex/kathylatour  Kathy LaTour of CURE magazine writes: Here are some facts about Komen and the money they raise. The 127 races that are held by Komen affiliates around the world raise a lot of money--yes. And 75 percent of those funds stay in the community where they were raised to be used on all kinds of breast cancer related needs. Each affiliate sets its own guidelines, but they award grants in their area to non-profits, including hospitals, that provide such services as screening, diagnostics, and treatment as well as programs to educate and raise awareness. Some fund services such as expenses for survivors like transportation to treatment. In the '90s I was founding president of the board of two nonprofits in Dallas that addressed breast cancer. The first, a group called the Bridge Breast Network, assists uninsured women with diagnosis and treatment. We started the group with funding from memorials for my mother, who died of breast cancer in 1992, and then we had the very arduous task of fund raising for a start up that provided medical care for women with breast cancer. Had it not been for the Dallas Affiliate of Komen, we would never have gotten off the ground. And the women we served--all of whom did not have insurance and many of whom were minority--would not have had treatment. When we started Gilda's Club North Texas, the funding also came, albeit at lower amounts because we had to prove the numbers of our members that were breast cancer survivors. Komen affiliates do their homework on every grant. The other 25 percent of the money raised by the Komen affiliates goes back to Komen National and is directed to research - all of it. So where does the money come from to run the organization: corporate sponsors.[blog continues]

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2011 12:17PM - edited Jan 1, 2011 12:18PM by EnglishMajor http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/91/topic/699896?page=10#idx_297 See above thread (Before During & After Surgery) for helpful tips on what to take to the hospital, prepare at home, etc. Also, www.breastfree.org  has stories of women who didn't opt for recon.  Everyone is different. I had a pretty easy time--no nodes or recon so that significantly speeded recovery time. I didn't have much pain and felt pretty good afterwords, all things considered. Again, my prodedure was pretty minimal and everyone is different. I was very modestly endowed to begin with. I found I didn't use the surgical camisole--support was not an issue. (I was glad to have the option, tho.) I only had one drain (an advantage of being on the small side...) I didn't have any difficulties with my arm as no nodes were taken. I had rads a few weeks after the surgery--a bra would have been uncomfortable, I could get by with a tank top.  Most insurance will cover the cost of the surgical camisole, prothesis, etc. My treatment center has an "image center" where they fit and dispense these.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 08:27AM EnglishMajor wrote: I can't comment on the vaccination issue. But I would say MBC research is underfunded.  Here is July 2010 commentary from Kathy Miller:  Hi, Kathy Miller with Indiana University, back with another installment of our Medscape video oncology blog. Today it is another convergence of 2 seemingly unrelated issues that got me thinking. I spent a long time last night reviewing grants that have been just submitted, or rather, grant proposals, just submitted to the Komen Foundation, and there were some truly fabulous ideas there, really innovative ideas that might be wrong, but if they are right, have the potential to lead to really major improvements for our patients. And I kept getting more and more frustrated as I was reading these proposals, realizing that there simply is not enough funding to support all of the proposals that would really be worth funding, and that should be given the chance to be tested. And this morning, I came in early to see a patient before my usual clinic started -- a delightful young woman with advanced metastatic disease who was expressing her disappointment to me that with all the funding available for cancer research, that from her perspective, we have made very little progress. I have to say on one hand, that I disagree with her that we have made little progress. We have made some major progress in important areas over the past decade. But from her perspective, she is right: we don't have anything that is going to cure her of this breast cancer. She has done everything we have asked her to do from the time of her early diagnosis, and she knows she is going to die from this breast cancer and that is going to happen pretty soon. But it did get me thinking: is she right about the amount of funding? And it got me to look at the actual numbers. So here are 2 numbers for you to ponder and for you to think about the next time a patient of yours asks you about the lack of progress with the huge amount of funding. If you combine all of the funding for cancer research in this country from all sources (private foundations, pharmaceutical companies, the US government), and lump them all together, it comes to just under 69 cents per person per week for a disease that is consistently one of the most frightening, one of the most deadly diseases, one that will affect nearly half of us directly, and all of us indirectly. Just under 69 cents per week per person. Let me put that number in perspective for you. That is roughly one-sixth of what we, as a nation, spend on soft drinks. It is roughly one-third of the tobacco industry's advertising budget. So when you wonder why progress is not as quick as we would hope, the funding is not that great, and in comparison with other things that we freely spend money on that are not nearly so important or maybe frankly harmful, it puts the problem in a whole new light. It is really a problem of commitment and willingness to fund the endeavor in the necessary way to make progress. Something for us all to think about the next time we go to the vending machine and get our favorite soft drink.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2014 08:22AM EnglishMajor wrote: Echoing what stage free said--a disease (cancer or otherwise) is not a punishment or judgement against one's character. While we know, for example, that smoking can cause cancer, many people who smoked live to a good old age. And some who didn't died well before their time.  Consider Dana Reeve, Christopher "Superman" Reeve's wife. She died of lung cancer--she was not a smoker. I think she probably took excellent care of herself. Another good example is Linda McCartney, Paul McCartney's wife. Linda was a passionate vegetarian--at a time when it wasn't fashionable to be one. I am sure she took excellent care of herself--and she still got breast cancer.  There is a perception among some people that people get metastatic breast cancer because they did something wrong--ate or drank the wrong things, etc. etc. But on this board, as you will see, cancer doesn't care about gold stars in going to the gym or eating kale--it doesn't discriminate.  On the other hand, I would never take a "why bother" approach. We should be good to ourselves and take care of ourselves. But we can't take cancer as a personal failing--because it is not. It is a cellular disease. In some cases, we have inherited faulty genes in other cases, there may be environmental factors at work. Chin up, grasshopper!

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 10:44AM EnglishMajor wrote: This is personal decision--you have to do what is right for you. And of course, people have different experiences, what was easy for one woman may prove painful for another.  That being said... I had a left mx no recon followed by 30 rads because I had a close margin. I had a  big tumor and small breast, so  lumpectomy wasn't an option. I was pretty flat to begin with so balance and symmetry were not an issue for me. I wasn't offered recon, but wouldn't have opted for it. Because I was small to begin with, the mx did not make a huge difference in my shape. I was glad in retrospect to be recovering only from the simple mx vs. recon. which would taken a longer time.  Radiation made me tired toward the end. My skin held up pretty well, altho that is not the case for everyone. There is also the time commitment---having to go 30 consecutive days for tx (less weekends) can cramp your style. The tx is quick, but, like a suspect on a cop show, you can't leave town (well, only on weekends).... This was the right decision for me, good luck with your choice!

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 03:25PM EnglishMajor wrote: http://www.drivingmissdarby.org/  May all go well for you! No trial experience here, but for you and others, here's some info on an assn. created by Darby Steadman, herself a Stage IV bc patient, that helps with clinical trial expenses.  Darby's participation in Dr. Emens' breast cancer vaccine trial forever changed her perspective on medicine, convincing her of the importance of scientific research in the war on cancer. The result is Darby's passion for supporting patients who, like her, have chosen experimental treatment for their disease. The truth is that Darby's participation in this trial will likely not benefit her at all. She chose to participate in the trial hoping that her daughter will never face the same disease that both Darby and her mother have faced. Darby will use her foundation to promote scientific discovery and help facilitate access to experimental treatment for patients who otherwise could not afford it. The ability of our scientists to develop cutting edge clinical treatments will stagnate unless they can recruit and retain study patients, a process called accrual. Only then can our medical community put into practice the promising results of research such as Dr. Emens' vaccine work. Read more about the accrual crisis from the New York Times. Read more about the accrual crisis from the Wall Street Journal.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 07:56AM EnglishMajor wrote:  Hi Dola I am not a doctor or an expert in breast cancer with an unknown primary. There are some women here with unknown primaries whose cancer has spread, they can offer a better explanation.  Sometimes it does happen that a woman will have breast cancer which can't be seen in her breast but has spread nonetheless.  I would hazard to guess this is because cancer must have divided into millions of cells before we can see it, even with today's soposticated imaging devices. (I believe cancer must be 7mm or so before it can be seen.) At any rate, it's likely your friend has cancer in her breast, it just isn't detectable. Hope this helps. Other things to know: >Metastasis refers to the spread of cancer to different parts of the body, typically the bones, liver and lungs. >Treatment is lifelong and focuses on control and quality of life vs. cure >About 6% to 10% of women are Stage IV from their initial diagnosis. >Treatment choices for MBC are guided by hormone (ER/PR) and HER2 receptor status, location and extent of metastasis (visceral vs. nonvisceral), previous treatment and other factors.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2011 08:29PM EnglishMajor wrote:  Hi there, Here's the post referenced above...please check with PAF. Also:  If you are going to a treatment center, there should be a social worker who will know the best resources. If you haven't done so, tell your oncologist your concerns. This is an important part of your total health picture. Your doctor should know what is on your mind.  Hang in there. http://gallery.patientadvocate.org/requests/paf_cm_request.php http://www.patientadvocate.org/help.php?p=480#one What does PAF do? Patient Advocate Foundation is a national non-profit organization that serves as an active liaison between the patient and their insurer, employer and/or creditors to resolve insurance, job retention and/or debt crisis matters relative to their diagnosis through case managers, doctors and attorneys. Patient Advocate Foundation seeks to safeguard patients through effective mediation assuring access to care, maintenance of employment and preservation of their financial stability. Are your services free? Yes. Patient Advocate Foundation provides case management services, educational materials and live chat services at no charge to patients. How can I get case management assistance? If you have a chronic, debilitating or life threatening illness and would like to have direct communication with a member of PAF Patient Services, please call us at 800-532-5274. We have access to a wide variety of resources and can offer intervention if necessary. Do you offer financial assistance? We do not offer direct financial assistance. Please refer to our website www.patientadvocate.org for resources that may benefit you. You may search within "The National Financial Resources Guidebook" for National Resources, Government Resources and State-specific Resources. If you are in need of co-pay assistance, please contact our Co-Pay Relief Program at 1-866-512-3861. Can you help with transportation? Please refer to our website www.patientadvocate.org for resources that may benefit you. You may search within "The National Financial Resources Guidebook" for National Resources, Government Resources and State-specific Resources. Where can I get financial assistance for my living expenses such as rent, utilities and food? Please refer to our website www.patientadvocate.org for resources that may benefit you. You may search within "The National Financial Resources Guidebook" for National Resources, Government Resources and State-specific Resources. How can I get help with funeral expenses? If your loved one had no assets and was eligible for public assistance, you should contact either the Social Services/Medicaid case worker or Social Services General information to inquire about indigent funeral assistance. If he/she was a Veteran, you should contact the Veterans Administration to inquire about available benefits. You may also contact the Social Security Administration for assistance. If you are unsure of how to proceed, many funeral homes have access to information regarding the availability of state or local assistance. How can I get insurance if I have a pre-existing condition? You may visit www.healthinsurance.org/riskpo... to determine whether the state in which you reside offers a State Comprehensive Health Insurance Program also called a "risk pool". These programs offer access to health insurance for patients who are unable to obtain coverage elsewhere. Also, be sure to elect COBRA coverage when leaving an employer in order to prevent a gap in insurance coverage. If there has been no break in coverage and your spouse has insurance available through his or her employer, you should be able to access this benefit because of your 'qualifying event.'

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 05:29AM EnglishMajor wrote: http://thechart.blogs.cnn.com/2011/06/03/why-i-became-an-oncologist/  Oncologist ASCO Past President George Sledge:  Cancer doctors tend to get to their profession in one of three ways. Some are drawn in through their love of cancer science. Cancer has always been something like a cobra to those who study it: dangerous and beautiful and endlessly fascinating. Cancer is a universe. One can spend an entire life exploring it without ever getting bored, for the biology of cancer is the biology of life. Some doctors are inspired by a great teacher. Medicine is still a profession dominated by old-world apprenticeships, where a mentor's passion can be transmitted to a new generation. I have known several oncologists whose careers turned on chance encounters with inspiring professors. Others get there by way of their patients. I'm one of these. When I was a resident, cancer patients were the ones who touched my heart. In fact, I can remember the very moment I started my path to becoming an oncologist. [continues...]

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 09:14PM EnglishMajor wrote:  Some additional resources: Legal Help for Lower-Income Workers-- A number of regional legal networks operate to help patients dealing with job-related or insurance-related issues along with their cancer. Among them: * Legal Information Network for Cancer (LINC, www.cancerlinc.org, 877-644-5462). Services include explanation of insurance benefits and help with appeal for coverage denial; the getting of public benefits such as Medicaid or Social Security Disability, management of debt, including negotiation to ward off collections, arrangements for care and custody of children. * LegalHealth at the New York Legal Assistance Group has legal clinics for low-income patients in the New York area dealing with job and other issues, and other services (www.nylag.org, 212-613-5095). * Cancer Legal Resource Center (www.disabilityrightslegalcenter.org, 866-843-2572) in Los Angeles offers nationwide assistance with job and health insurance related issues. * The Patient Advocate Foundation (www.patientadvocate.org, 800-532-5274) offers counseling as well as referrals for cancer patients dealing with job discrimination, insurance issues and other problems. Payment for Treatments-- A number of nonprofit organizations can help with financial assistance when treatment expenses for cancer are overwhelming. A sampling: * CancerCare (www.cancercare.org, 800-813-4673), offers financial assistance in the form of limited grants for certain treatment expenses. Services also include practical help and support via the free phone line or the website. * National Marrow Donor Program (www.marrow.org, 888-999-6743) has a patient assistance program that helps with costs for searching the donor program registry and some post-transplant costs. * The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society (www.leukemia-lymphoma.org, 800-955-4572) offers some financial aid to patients with leukemia, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma or multiple myeloma who qualify as needing the assistance. * The Patient Advocate Foundation (www.patientadvocate.org, 800-532-5274) also sponsors a Co-Pay Relief program for qualified patients. * The Federal Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) Bureau of Primary Health Care has health centers nationwide that provide health care based on ability to pay. To locate a health center, visit the web page at http://ask.hrsa.gov/pc. Payment for Medications-- Relief from the high costs of medications is often needed. Among the organizations that help: * NeedyMeds, at www.needymeds.com, is a nonprofit that helps patients by referring them to patient assistance programs to help with medication costs. * Patient assistance programs are offered by some pharmaceutical companies. To find them, ask your doctor or social worker or find the drug's manufacturer and visit the company site. Look for a section titled "patience assistance programs" or similar wording. Payment for Transportation and Lodging * Hope Lodge is a housing program supported by the American Cancer Society, providing free housing on a temporary basis for cancer patients undergoing treatment. For information and a listing of lodges, visit the web site at www.cancer.org/docroot/subsite... or call 800-227-2345. * Road to Recovery, another ACS program, offers transportation to and from treatments for cancer patients. More information is available by calling your local ACS office or the toll-free national number, 800-227-2345.
