Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2011 08:53PM EnglishMajor wrote:  No doubt. The following doesn't address the issue you raise, but it's an article that resonated with me.  Take care Seven Tips For Getting What You Need... Dr. Larry Norton Larry Norton, M.D. Deputy Physician-in-Chief for Breast Cancer Programs; Medical Director, Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center; Norna S. Sarofim Chair of Clinical Oncology, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center 1. If you have trouble making a decision, you don't know enough. If you gather enough information, the decision will make itself. 2. Make sure you communicate. You need to say to your doctor, "I'm here to get better," not, "Don't hurt me." If you're communicating that you are not interested in toxicity, then you may miss out on a treatment that could save your life. 3. If you don't like your doctor, your doctor probably doesn't like you. Don't stay with a physician with whom you're not comfortable. Don't force a relationship to work that isn't working. 4. You want a doctor to say, "Here are the best options for you," not, " This is what I can do for you." Doctors should be willing to look beyond their own knowledge to other experts for the best treatment. 5. When you think of your future, visualize positive things happening. 6. You are more than your body. Use your whole self to help yourself. 7. Don't forget the moment. Be in the moment and enjoy it. Sometimes patients get so focused on what happened in the past or what might happen in the future, they miss the moments they have.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 05:16PM EnglishMajor wrote: The single most important predictive factor in cancer is Performance Status (‘functional ability,’ ‘functional status’): a measure of how much a patient can do for themselves, their activity and energy level. Most cancer centers have a social worker or counselor who can help with end of life issues. Counselors, like doctors, know that sometimes people need to find a better fit--I would ask the counselor for a referral. Have you had any interaction with your mom's doctors? Because of privacy laws, the doctor might need some kind of ok before he can talk to you (HIPPA consent) Take care

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2011 04:35AM EnglishMajor wrote: I have used Caring Bridge and also have a blog Caring Bridge Pros:  > "One and Done" message posting eliminates sending email bulletins, fielding phone calls, etc.  > Central place to track details as they are unfolding if newly dx'd or having a treatment/health crisis >Different levels of security so you are not "sharing with the world" if you choose not to (As you say, FB isn't the best forum for maintaining some privacy) >Free! Caring Bridge Cons: >Some older friend and family aren't computer savvy (but their kids generally pass along the CB update). (Of course this issue isn't restricted to CB and extends to cell phones, fancy TVs, etc.) >Seemingly one or two people will lose their passwords and rather than reset them (very easy) will ask for news via email (kind of defeating the purpose of the whole thing, but there's always a few people unclear on the concept) >Context must be provided for any medical news. Example: Tumor Marker rises but barely perceptible. Some readers might take this as really bad news, when it is kind of a routine thing,  >Lack of activity due to excellent health can be misconstrued as "Must be bad news--she's so depressed/incapicated she can't post," or "I wonder what's REALLY going on." (Answer: Absolutely nothing.) >Communication can be one way--it can feel weird to share some piece of news which elicits no comment--not because people aren't reading or don't care--some are just shy and some don't know what to say.  >Regardless of how clearly you spell out your diagnosis/latest development, a few people either won't rememeber or cope via denial. I think CB  is best if you have ongoing medical news and want a reasonably secure place to share details and your own thoughts. It is better than an email group message which can result in a lot of invidual messsages that can cover the same ground.  CB users can sign up to get an email notification of a new post. Some people don't sign up for this, and, if you are not posting regularly, may not keep up with you. A blog (Wordpressis also very easy) is good for pushing out infornation. Most sites have privacy settings so you can have a "closed" blog if you want.   www.carepages.com/ is similar to Caring Bridge.

My mom had inflammatory breast cancer--people did not talk much about any cancer then--this was before BC Awareness month, the pink ribbon etc. My mom was a quiet person--I don't think she would've gone to a support group, but wow, she would have loved the Internet...I don't think she ever met anyone with MBC let alone IBC. I haven't posted to my FB yet, but I will. The other day I posted an old picture of my mom and mentioned I couldn't believe it had been 30 years since she died from inflammatory breast cancer. One of my FB friends responded: So sad. Cancer treatment has come a long way, seems like you hear more good stories than bad these days. A friend here had stage 4 melanoma and is now clean, almost unheard of before I know she meant well, but I just couldn't go along with that. My response Unfortunately, there is much progress to be made with metastatic breast cancer. As my friend and fellow advocate Shirley Mertz just told the Houston Chronicle: "Nearly 40,000 women and men die every year, and that number hasn’t changed in two decades.” http://blog.chron.com/boomertown/2013/08/fighting-breast-cancer-one-day-one-week-one-month-at-a-time/

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2013 12:34AM EnglishMajor wrote: Hi Tasha, from the sound of things, your doctor just wants to make sure he has a thorough idea of where you are today (in terms of the disease) so he will know how you are doing in follow up scans. Unless you had reported a  new symptom (such as blurred vision or being dizzy) it's unlikely he is suspecting brain mets. Brain mets generally require swift investigation/action, so if that was a concern, he would likely have sent you for the MRI right that day and you would see him sooner vs. later. Generally speaking, people with HER2+ disease are a higher risk for brain mets: Breast cancer metastasizes (spreads) to the brain in about 15-20% of women with metastatic disease. However, some factors put patients at higher risk. Women who are under fifty years of age, who have HER2 positive tumors, estrogen receptor-negative tumors, and lung or liver metastases are somewhat more likely to be diagnosed with brain metastases. Studies indicate that mutations in the BRCA1 gene are also a risk factor (Source: http://www.brainmetsbc.org/en/content/frequently-asked-questions-about-brain-metastasis) Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2012 03:22PM - edited Apr 17, 2012 03:26PM by EnglishMajor Just wanted to say hang in there... In general it's probably true that bone-only disease is "better" than having organ involvement. But there are no hard or fast rules. Being ER/PR+ is "good" in that you likely have more tx options. Some drs. say that disease "tempo" is a key factor--having five years between your original dx and mets is "good" in that indicates slow tempo.  Stable is definitely awesome! Beats the heck out of progression any day!!  Susan Davis, a tireless volunteer with the MBCN, said it best. Susan lived with mets for almost a dozen years. Although she endured progressively more grueling treatments, she said ultimately even the harshest side effects weren't as difficult as the mental fight. "I live in a constant state of hopeful dread," she wrote. "I am hopeful I will be stable. I dread that my next test will show I am not."  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 12:28PM EnglishMajor wrote: My PCP was on top of things. But in a subsquent visit, when talking about MBC, I really felt like he didn't get it. I had to drop off an insurance form, so I also included this story (which features who Suzanne Hebert, a later member of this boad). http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/18/health/18cancer.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 I like the idea of education...print this out and highlight #8? 13 Facts Everyone Should Know about Metastatic Breast Cancer (click HERE to download a flyer you can print and distribute) 1. No one dies from breast cancer that remains in the breast. Metastasis occurs when cancerous cells travel to a vital organ and that is what threatens life. 2. Metastasis refers to the spread of cancer to different parts of the body, typically the bones, liver, lungs and brain. 3. An estimated 155,000 Americans are currently living with metastatic breast cancer. Metastatic breast cancer accounts for approximately 40,000 deaths annually in the U.S. 4. Treatment for metastatic breast cancer is lifelong and focuses on control of the disease and quality of life. 5. About 6% to 10% of people are Stage IV from their initial diagnosis. 6. Early detection does not guarantee a cure. Metastatic breast cancer can occur 5, 10 or 15 years after a person’s original diagnosis and successful treatment checkups and annual mammograms. 7. 20% to 30% of people initially diagnosed with early stage disease will develop metastatic breast cancer. 8. Young people, as well as men, can be diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer. 9. Like early stage breast cancer, there are different types of metastatic breast cancer. 10. Treatment choices are guided by breast cancer type, location and extent of metastasis in the body, previous treatments and other factors. 11.Metastatic breast cancer is not an automatic death sentence. Although most people will ultimately die of their disease, some will live long and productive lives. 12. There are no definitive prognostic statistics for metastatic breast cancer. Every patient and their disease is unique. 13. To learn more about National Metastatic Breast Cancer Awareness Day on October 13 and to access resources specifically for people living with metastatic breast cancer and their caregivers, visit www.mbcn.org.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2013 02:49PM EnglishMajor wrote: I didn't notice that either...but it looks like the mods corrected it. I haven't been following Robin's story. There is part of me that would quit work right away--I have other ways to fill my time. But I think of a work friend of mine, a guy who was 51. He was dx'd with some kind of mouth cancer. We don't work for the same people but we are in the same industry. When I learned he was sick, I sent him a card but I never heard from him. (He couldn't talk on the phone, so calling him was out.) Anyhow, my friend was always a bit of a loner--didn't have close family, not married and a bit of a workaholic. Head and neck cancers ofen carry a grim prognosis and such was his case, altho he was determined to keep working. Because of the radiation, he could no longer speak--I guess he emailed his coworkers to have work discussions (tho they were in the same office). He couldn't eat well--he was always a thin guy and was visibly weakened by his tx. Because of the tx, he had difficulty swallowing and would sometimes be making choking noises. He worked in a cubicle. An empty office was availabe and his boss offered to let him have it. My friend refused. He may have felt it was less about making a compassionate gesture to him and more about making everyone else more comfortable. I had assumed that with chemo and rads he was getting there was no way he would or could continue to work. But he did. A little more than a year after his dx he died on his way to work. He collapsed in lobby of his condo building--I think his heart probably gave out. In writing to his colleagues, I reflected that going to work gave my friend a purpose and distraction. It's not what I would choose, but for him it was a good thing. So who knows, maybe that's how it is for Robin. Wish her the best.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2010 11:56AM EnglishMajor wrote:  Surgery is not standard of care for Stage IV, but in certain cases there is thought to be some benefit. Typically surgery would only be done if the disease in good control. If there was visceral involvement, surgery probably wouldn't be done.  I don't think that tumor removal could accelerate the spread of the disease. But equally important, there is no guarantee that having the surgery will benefit your MIL. Ultimately it is your MIL's choice.  I have a low volume of bone mets and had a mastectomy this past May. If you do a search on thi site you will find additional discussions.  [from a previous thread] AnnNYC AnnNYC wrote: Hi Donna -- I hope you don't mind my posting the following literature links (this kind of literature search and review is part of what I do for a living). There are in fact recent (2006-2008)retrospective studies showing an overall survival benefit -- and even more of a progression-free survival benefit -- with removal of an intact primary tumor in women who are diagnosed at Stage IV, especially in women who are ER+ and have only bone mets. These are probably some of the studies Becky shared with English Major -- and like English Major said, they are all retrospective "chart reviews" comparing the outcomes in women who had surgery to women who didn't. So the results may be biased -- the women who had surgery may have been chosen to have it because they were healthier, or the fact that they had surgery may just have been part of their having more "involved" care from their doctors -- so that's why the prospective trial English Major mentioned is so important. But still, here is a summary of reports that found a benefit: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16614878Babiera Babiera GV, et al. Effect of primary tumor extirpation in breast cancer patients who present with stage IV disease and an intact primary tumor. Annals of Surgical Oncology 2006;13:776-782. M.D. Anderson, Houston, TX -- All (224) breast cancer patients treated at M.D. Anderson between 1997 and 2002 who presented with stage IV disease and an intact primary tumor. CONCLUSIONS: Removal of the intact primary tumor for breast cancer patients with synchronous stage IV disease is associated with improvement in metastatic progression-free survival. Prospective studies are needed to validate these findings. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17522944 Gnerlich J, et al. Surgical removal of the primary tumor increases overall survival in patients with metastatic breast cancer: analysis of the 1988-2003 SEER data. Annals of Surgical Oncology 2007;14:2187-2194. A retrospective, population-based cohort study by using the 1988-2003 Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program data: 9734 SEER patients with stage IV breast cancer. CONCLUSIONS: Extirpation of the primary breast tumor in patients with stage IV disease was associated with a marked reduction in risk of dying after controlling for variables associated with survival. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/p ubmed/17687611 Fields RC, et al. Surgical resection of the primary tumor is associated with increased long-term survival in patients with stage IV breast cancer after controlling for site of metastasis. Annals of Surgical Oncology 2007;14:3345-3351. Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO - 409 patients with stage IV breast cancer treated from 1996 to 2005. CONCLUSIONS: Surgical excision of the primary breast tumor was associated with significantly longer survival in this cohort of stage IV breast cancer patients, even after controlling for other factors associated with survival. Randomized clinical trials are needed to validate these findings. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18438108 Blanchard DK, et al. Association of surgery with improved survival in stage IV breast cancer patients. Annals of Surgery 2008;247:732-738. Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX - 807 women with stage IV disease at presentation. CONCLUSION: Patients with stage IV breast cancer who had definitive surgical treatment of their primary tumors had more favorable disease characteristics. However, after adjustment for these characteristics, surgical treatment remained an independent factor associated with improved survival. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18357493 Rao R, et al. Timing of surgical intervention for the intact primary in stage IV breast cancer patients. Annals of Surgical Oncology 2008;15:1696-702. University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas - review of all breast cancer patients between 1997 and 2002 presenting with an intact tumor and synchronous metastatic disease. Patients who underwent surgery in the 3-8.9 month or later period had improved metastatic progression-free survival. CONCLUSIONS: Surgical extirpation of the primary tumor in patients with synchronous stage IV disease is associated with improved metastatic PFS when performed more than 3 months after diagnosis. Resection should be planned with the intent of obtaining negative margins. HOWEVER, this paper from Brigham and Women's in Boston does NOT see any real benefit: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18581232 Bafford AC et al. Breast surgery in stage IV breast cancer: impact of staging and patient selection on overall survival. Breast Cancer Research and Treatment 2009;115:7-12 Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston - Review of prospectively maintained database of 147 women who presented with stage IV breast cancer between 1998 and 2005. CONCLUSIONS: Breast surgery is associated with improved survival in stage IV breast cancer. However, in our experience, this benefit is only realized among patients operated on before diagnosis of metastatic disease and is likely a consequence of stage migration bias. While some women may warrant palliative surgery to the breast, it is unclear that such surgery otherwise improves clinical outcomes. The possible biases in these retrospective studies are summed up well in this editorial (the link should take you to the whole article): http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2077920/?tool=pubmed Khan SA. Primary Tumor Resection in Stage IV Breast Cancer: Consistent Benefit, or Consistent Bias? Annals of Surgical Oncolog 2007;14:3285-3287 ...five retrospective studies... present us with consistent evidence that either surgical therapy of the primary tumor has a substantial survival benefit in women with metastatic breast cancer, or there is a strong and consistent selection bias driving the use of surgery in women who have more favorable profiles (i.e., younger age, smaller tumor burden, better access to care). It is also possible that surgery is a surrogate indicator of more aggressive therapy overall, including more aggressive systemic therapy, which translates into better survival. All authors acknowledge the problem of selection bias in the interpretation of these data, and all advocate for a randomized trial to settle this question.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 11:44AM EnglishMajor wrote:  No advce, but as always, check with your doctor before taking anything. Some antidepressants can interfere with tamozifen's effectiveness.   Hang in there http://www.womensmentalhealth.org/posts/interactions-between-antidepressants-and-tamoxifen/ Tamoxifen’s effects in the breast depend on its ability to antagonize estrogen. Tamoxifen’s anti-estrogen affinity is thought to depend on the activity of its primary metabolite, endoxifen. Tamoxifen is metabolized to endoxifen through the liver enzyme CYP2D6. Consequently, any co-administered agent that inhibits this enzyme will reduce the conversion of tamoxifen to endoxifen, thereby potentially reducing the efficacy of tamoxifen as a breast cancer therapy (Jin et al, 2005). Many commonly used antidepressants are CYP2D6 inhibitors, thus clinicians and patients must consider possible interactions when using these treatments in women taking tamoxifen.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 05:45PM EnglishMajor wrote:  Sorry, can't offer any specific help.  As noted below, some pain medicine can make people dizzy. Anyone (including air travelers) who remains sitting or lying down  for  long  periods is susceptible to blood clots (one leg swells, the other doesn't. Could also be red/warm.) So that' something to be aware of. I am pretty sure  the ER would check for these things.   I hope your MIL will get some relief soon.  http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/side_effects/dizziness.jsp Dizziness can be caused by a sudden drop in blood pressure or from being dehydrated. If you get up too quickly from a sitting- or lying-down position, you might feel lightheaded. Some women feel dizzy while they're having a hot flash. Several breast cancer treatments can cause dizziness: In addition, some antihistamines, antiseizure medications, antidepressants, and tranquilizers can cause dizziness. Many pain medications can also make you dizzy. http://www.livestrong.com/article/95897-symptoms-blood-clot-foot-leg/ When a clot forms in the deep veins of the legs, it can either partially or totally block the venous return to the heart. According to Clot Care, larger blood clots in the major veins will cause swelling and pain in the affected leg, lower than the clot. The pain in the leg is often worse with standing or walking and is caused from the lack of oxygen supply to the muscles required for balance and walking. The increased workload during standing and walking leads to a greater oxygen demand. Because the muscles aren't being supplied with oxygen, pain is the result. Read more: www.livestrong.com/article/958...#ixzz1Afozacub     http://www.spine-health.com/conditions/leg-pain/causes-leg-pain-and-foot-pain As we age, our intervertebral discs dehydrate (lose water), degenerate, lose their flexibility and allow small movements, which can cause pain from the disc that may radiate down the leg. While the primary symptom of lumbar degenerative disc disease is usually low back pain, leg pain and foot pain are also common symptoms. When lumbar degenerative disc diseasepresents with leg pain and/or foot pain, this is called “referred pain”. Another common example of referred pain includes neck/arm or shoulder pain caused by heart attacks. The brain cannot always distinguish exactly where the pain source is, and so feels pain more vaguely in multiple areas. Referred pain is typically dull, achy, and  poorly localized.   Spinal stenosis in the low back occurs when the spinal nerve roots are compressed or choked, usually by enlarged facet joints located in the back of the spinal column. Spinal stenosis usually, but not always, occurs in elderly patients as the facet joints enlarge due to degeneration of the spine that tends to occur with age. The narrowing can be confirmed with an MRI scan. The symptoms of spinal stenosis are often referred to as sciatica - leg pain, radiating pain, tingling, leg weakness and/or numbness. Doctors usually use the words radiculopathy or radiculitis to describe the same symptoms. The leg pain from stenosis tends to develop gradually over time (mirroring the cumulative narrowing process taking place in the spine as the facet joints enlarge). Spinal stenosis symptoms tend to improve when the patient leans forward, a position that has the effect of opening up the back of the spinal column, taking pressure off the spinal nerve roots.

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 01:01PM EnglishMajor wrote: http://neurosurgery.mgh.harvard.edu/abta/mets.htm#SYMPTOMS_3  Hope your MIL is doing better. Maybe this link can help you eliminate some causes. Take care SYMPTOMS OF METASTATIC BRAIN TUMORS HEADACHE: Headache is caused by stretching of sensitive structures such as blood vessels or nerves due to edema, spinal fluid obstruction or tumor growth, or by injury to the brain caused by the tumor. Initially, the headache comes and goes, and is usually more common in the morning, just after awakening. It gradually increases in duration and frequency. Ataxia is more common in people with spinal fluid obstruction, or with tumors involving the cerebellum. Cerebellar tumors often cause dizziness and vomiting.

There's more:  Iowan Sally Drees is determined to raise $41,000 before October ends ("41k in 31 Days"). $20,500 will go to The Pink Daisy Project, a nonprofit that provides support to breast cancer patients under age 45. The remaining $20,500 will go to METAvivor, a nonprofit, volunteer-run group that funds metastatic breast cancer research. Why $41,000? "Each dollar represents one person in the U.S. who will die of breast cancer this year," Drees explains. "I believe less pink and more green will make a world of difference this October." http://www.causes.com/causes/632480-the-31-day-project-moving-beyond-awareness The late Jane Soyer and Nina Schulman founded the Metastatic Breast Cancer Network (MBCN) in 2004. MBCN is a national, independent, patient-led, nonprofit advocacy group that provides education and information on treatments and coping with the disease. See www.mbcn.org. This October I will remember playwright and actress Oni Faida Lampley (1959-2008). "Perhaps the hardest part was my fear that those who loved me would be disappointed if I ceased to be the do-it-all survivor...Over time, I let that go, too. I prayed, slept, cried and (don't tell anybody) felt sorry for myself, and-lo and behold, the roof didn't fall in!" http://www.theonifund.com/biography.html#self National Metastatic Breast Cancer Awareness Day is Oct. 13. Who will you remember? This October, I will remember NC State basketball coach Kay Yow (1942-2009). Yow had surgery for breast cancer in the summer of 1987, but the cancer returned in November 2004. In 2006 after being dx'd with liver mets she took a 16-game leave of absence, but returned to take the Wolfpack to the Round of 16 of the 2007 N.C.A.A. tournament. http://www.alumni.ncsu.edu/s/1209/index.aspx?sid=1209&gid=1&pgid=546 National Metastatic Breast Cancer Awareness Day is Oct. 13. Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2010 12:46AM EnglishMajor wrote:  One thing I don't think I was clear on... It's somewhat unusual to be Stage IV (i.e., have mets) from the get go. That only happens to about six percent of people. Most womwen who go on to have mets were previously treated for an earlier stage of cancer and therefore would alread have had surgery.  Once cancer has spread outside of the breast, treatment is different. While it's possible remove a breast/tumor, I have spine mets. They can't remove the affected bone(s). To a degree, earlier stage breast cancer is a sprint; MBC is a marathon.  I put this in a different post, but in case you didnt see it:  There are several phone hotlines that will match breast cancer patients (and their caregivers)  to someone with a similar diagnosis/stage. Below is info on the "Your Shoes" and other programs. It can be very helpful to even have one phone call with a "veteran" cancer patient. See what you think: Breast Cancer Network of Strength (formerly Y-Me National Breast Cancer Foundation) 1-800-221-2141 (YourShoes, 24-hr hotline) 1-800-986-9505 (Spanish) www.networkofstrength.org The mission of Breast Cancer Network of Strength is to ensure, through information, empowerment and peer support, that no one faces breast cancer alone. YourShoes is Breast Cancer Network of Strength's peer support program that includes a 24/7 breast cancer support center staffed by trained breast cancer survivors providing peer support through a toll-free hotline, e-mail and support groups. http://www.lbbc.org/Learning-From-Others/Survivors-Helpline When you have questions, need someone to listen or don't know where to turn, call Living Beyond Breast Cancer's Survivors' Helpline. Your call will be answered by another woman who knows what you're feeling - a woman who has experienced breast cancer. Someone who cares. Someone who understands. Whatever your circumstances, we can help. Call us toll-free today: (888) 753-LBBC (5222). http://www.imermanangels.org/

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 11:10PM EnglishMajor wrote:  http://www.boston.com/business/healthcare/articles/2011/01/05/testing_rules_force_patients_to_wait_for_new_drugs/  Thanks 33! Here is an excerpt:  On first meeting, you would not guess that Lorraine Heidke-McCartin, a cheerful woman who raised four children, has been battling an aggressive form of breast cancer since 2006. During that time, Heidke-McCartin, 54, has experienced heartening victories and wrenching setbacks. Last summer, her hopes were buoyed when her doctors said she was a good candidate to take a promising experimental drug at Boston's Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. The treatment, called T-DM1, had reduced patients' tumors - with few side effects - during clinical trials. "They were feeling very encouraged about this drug,'' Heidke-McCartin recalled. "I said, ‘Can I tell my kids this is good news?' '' Yes, her doctors said. But in late August, shortly before the treatments were to start under a so-called expanded access program, the drug's maker, the Genentech division of Roche Holding AG, shut down the program in Boston after the Food and Drug Administration refused to speed the approval process. The about-face underscores the plight of thousands of patients whose lives can be thrown into upheaval by decisions about who can receive experimental drugs. Desperate to regain their health, they might be willing to try almost any treatment, even if it is unproven. But regulators and companies also must make sure a drug that is initially effective does not later prove to be dangerous. That requires years of clinical trials. And to make trials scientifically valid, some patients enrolled in them - no matter how ill - don't receive the drug being tested. In certain cases, however, "compassionate use'' of experimental drugs is permitted through expanded access programs, like the one Heidke-McCartin was headed for in Boston. Four months after the Dana-Farber program was scrapped because the FDA denied accelerated approval, she is still fighting HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer. But she is finally taking T-DM1, which combines Genentech's powerful antibody with a cancer-killing agent made by a Waltham biotechnology company, ImmunoGen Inc. To get it, she must travel to a hospital in Fairfax, Va. - every month, at her own expense. The 950-mile round trips are exhausting, but Heidke-McCartin said she manages because of her faith, her husband, Phil McCartin - who has been her chief medical advocate - and her growing family, including five grandchildren born since her diagnosis. "I was ready to give up,'' she said, describing side effects from other cancer drugs that ranged from nausea and hair loss to yellowed palms. "Then I would look at my grandchildren and get back on my feet again.'' Genentech is moving forward with the regulatory approval process for T-DM1, but based on the current FDA timetable, it won't reach the market before 2013. For now, it's available only to patients in trials and those eligible for treatment at 13 expanded access sites across the country - none within 450 miles of Boston.Continued...

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2014 11:50AM - edited Apr 13, 2014 11:52AM by EnglishMajor Hi BLV,  When I was dx'd five years ago, I had that same fear. I also worked for a large company. Cancer is considered a disability under the Americans With Disabilty Act. No company with a responsible HR department would risk letting you go on some flimsy pretext because you have cancer. If you have an exemplary work record it would look mighty suspicious if you were cut loose on some trumped up excuse.  In my case, I felt it was certain that my job would end--NOT due to the cancer but because the area I worked in was struggling and there was no way to justify my ongoing employment--or that of several other departments. I was ultimately let go--but it was part of general layoff, it had nothing to do with my "burden" on insurance costs. (So I couldn't claim I was discriminated against.)  I was fortunate to find another job with benefits.  Now, with the Affordable Healthcare Act, I have somewhat less fear as I know I could not be denied insurance and (hopefully) it would indeed be affordable.  Loyola U. has a free Disability Law Center, should you have concerns your emloyer is discrimating against you:  http://www.disabilityrightslegalcenter.org/contact... Cancer and Careers is good, too http://www.cancerandcareers.org/en/at-work/Legal-a...

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2011 05:05PM EnglishMajor wrote: Joy--my mother died of inflammatory breast cancer in 1983. Treatments were harsh and my mom's QOL generally wasn't too good. I have to repeat what my doctor told me: We aren't driving the same cars, using the same computers, phones, etc. as in my mom's day. (Remember when cell phones were the size of a brick??) I don't wear Dippty Do in my hair any more (I was young, that's my excuse), neon colors or Flashdance type ripped sweatshirts and leggings. Times and treatments do change. And everyone is different when it comes to treatment and response.   When I was diagnosed, I immediately thought everything that happened to my mom would happen to me.That's not the case. I believe my mom had a radical mactectomy--they now do a modified version. I also didn't realize that there are many different kinds of breast cancer. My mom had inflammatory BC--I don't. My breast cancer has different treament options. I have been stable on tamoxifen for more than a year with basically no side effects. We are all individuals--my response doesn't mean someone else might not have a different reaction.  Altho I have metastatic breast cancer (low volume to bones only) I am fortunate in that I still do everything I used to do (work, travel, watch bad TV, procrastinate about cleaning the bathroom/doing laundry). Again, we are all individuals and my experience is unique to me. But your friend might want to talk to some one "in her shoes."  Here's a program she might consider: Call 1-800-221-2141 or e-mail us now. At the heart of Y-ME National Breast Cancer OrganizationTM is the YourShoes® 24/7 Breast Cancer Support Center, the only place in the world where someone can call - 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year - and talk to a breast cancer survivor and be understood in 150 languages.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2014 09:32PM EnglishMajor wrote: I was interviewed for a free magazine distributed to oncologist's waiting rooms three or four years ago. I stressed that as someone with hormone receptor positive bone-only disease my reality was different from someone with say, triple negative, extensive organ involvement. At that time I was on tamoxifen, zoladex and zometa. Another Stage IV woman was also interviewed for a separate story. Both stories were very peppy and upbeat. I am a fairly sarcastic and cynical person--but every quote attributed to me was relentlessly positive--I sounded like Rebecca of Metastatic Farms....the other woman, whom I had met very briefly, was my flipside--she really was that cheerful. Unfortunately, her breast cancer was far more aggressive than mine--and she died about year after the article was published. So even the rare articles about someone in long term treatment don't tend to be very realistic...

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 03:39PM EnglishMajor wrote: I think there is another potential issue beyond indifference. Most doctors are guide by "standard of care". For Stage IV, it's the least toxic treatment first. So when my mets were found, I went from the premets plan (mx, rads, chemo) to a bottle of Tamoxiphen.  I have to concede it didn't feel like "they" were doing anything. But that is the established treatment for someone in my shoes. Tho of course I did not want mets, I am glad my nonagressive cancer could be treated with Tamoxifen first. Surgery is not standard of care for Stage IV, but there is thought to be some benefit. My doctor went over the pros and cons and stressed that the decision was mine.  Below is a link  to the Third consensus on medical treatment of metastatic breast cancer  Reading this helped me grasp the big picture and kind of know what I might expect down the road for tx.   http://annonc.oxfordjournals.org/content/20/11/1771.full I like the people at my treatment center, but it is a big place and not immune to bureaucratic challenges. Early stage women have a half day orientation session to the hospital where they learn about the various departments etc. I came to this center as a second opinion. I did not have surgery right away as an early stage woman would. So I did not get the "playbook" they distribute during the orientation session. This wasn't staff indifference as much as perhaps an innocent oversight...

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 06:06AM EnglishMajor wrote: treatment is also guided by "co-morbidities" (ie other health conditions a person might have);  age and or menopausal status, hormone receptor status (for example somone who is triple negastive won't benefit from antihormonal drugs; similarly Herceptin is appropriate for triple positive breast cancer but not ER/PR+ HER2-) and prior treatment for breast cancer (if any).

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2009 09:29PM EnglishMajor wrote: I can't address your specific situation. I don't have liver mets (as far as I know). But I just came from an u/s and PET scan (reported to hospital at 8:00; finished at 3:30. It was a stressful day. I wasn't told to bring my films (figured why bother, that was a mammogram, this is an u/s) or other records. (Gave my doc the whole file, pile of reports and CDs and stupidly assumed the relevant details were now on file.)  I know breast tumors sizes are sometimes given other more familar equivalents. (A  Double AA battery, for example.) Well mine feels as big as a hummingbird and doesn't seem to be shrinking. So no great hopes for the u/s. Didn't know if I would get results on the same day, I did previously.   Huge delay to get the u/s because I wasn't told to bring orignal films and prior u/s.  Plus, there happended to be many  complicated cases prior to me. I was quite short with the nurse, especially as the time drew near to the PET. You can't mess with the PET schedule. "Is there a problem here?" asked the radiologist (whom I have never met). I apologized for my bad temper which I think is fueled by uncertainty/anxiety about these tests. "There are books you can read," says  radiologist, eager to brand me  as crazy AND terminal. She specifically cited Elizabeth Kulbler Ross. I nearly gagged. EKR??? I had to read that in high school more than two decades ago. This is her frame of reference???  She also cited some relative with colon cancer. Because everyone knows someone with cancer and that helps them understand what exactly what I am going thru.  After waiting three hours for u/s, had to go to PET and then come back. PET took  2.5 hours, as expected.  Came home and had several glasses of wine. Doc did not call, so I can look forward to that call at work tommorrow.   Which is all a long way around the barn to saying, I don't usually come home and have a drink, but tonight I really neeeded one, and  I enjoyed it!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 04:03PM EnglishMajor wrote: It used to be women with Stage IV didn' have their primary tumor removed. Retrospective data has shown some considerable benefit in terms of survival. So while I won't have a mastectomy right away (as I would if the cancer was just confined to the breast) it will be reconsidered in a couple of months. So my answer is "maybe". I am in my 40s and in general good health. While the bone biopsy (done under twilight anthathesia) did not hurt per se, I was moving v. gingerly for a couple days after and I did need pain meds.  Your doc might not be trying to scare you--there might be specifc reasons not to do a biopsy. It is good you are seeking a second opinion.

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 04:55PM EnglishMajor wrote: I think that's a tough question because I have only seen two.. but here goes.... >Must have strong professional qualifications based on ranking from other doctors as well as patients.  >Must be well versed in metastatic breast cancer (vs. "generalist" ) >Must have access to leading reasearch and facilities  >Must be a strong communicator with good people skills, especially listening >Must be take a collaborative approach--present the options but let me decide  >Must "keep it real." First doctor positioned herself as the beacon of knowlege, bravely helping me face this uncertain and rocky future (practically had her own John Williams theme song swelling up in the background; second doctor is what you see is what you get, which I like better) >Must have good support staff who are proactive and responsive to inquiries >Must know pitfalls of own insitution and help me navigate (communicate well with other doctors I might have to see)   Overall, mine is pretty good.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 04:32AM EnglishMajor wrote: I think biopsies are mostly done to establish a metastatic diagnosis. If you have mets, they likely would not biopsy unless there was an unsolved question. My oncologist said lung nodules are a dime a dozen, not necess mets. If was seen before and is getting bigger or there are more of them, that is different. I had a bone biopsy as part of my original dx...to prove what was seen on the bone scan was in fact mets. Sclerotic means scar like and thus something healed....not necess mets. Something lytic ie Swiss cheese like would be more concerning. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2016 11:52PM EnglishMajor wrote: oh yeah. I was just thinking about this today...when I was a younger person, death was an abstraction...old people died--but I was not old. Having just turned 50, I am not as young as I used to be but hopefully not as old as I am going to be either... I think there were a few college bull sessions where kids thought in romantic terms ("I want black roses at my funeral," I remember some guy saying.) In terms of cancer it is truly a roller coaster. When first dx'd, I thought I would be making a quick exit. When I did not and enjoyed some years of stability, I think I got a little complacent. You know, death was something that happened to others. Maybe I was just lucky. Then when I had significant progression, I was kind of back to the way I felt during the first weeks/months of my diagnosis. Then things kind of swung back the other way as I didnt' have to drastically change tx and feel pretty good. I thing I sometimes engage in mental games of "Would You Rather"....ie "Would You Rather Pop Off Quickly or Linger For Awhile With Uncertain QOL...." Then I think, "If I have time to be doing all this thinking things are pretty darn good because if the shyst was truly hitting the fan at the moment, I would be way too busy/frantic and/or debilitated to do anything but concentrate on being alive. . ."

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2012 05:05PM - edited Jul 17, 2012 05:07PM by EnglishMajor I had a laproscopic ("keyhole") oopherctomy last month. I took it easy the first couple days, but was ok. I didn't have a lot of pain and no after effects from the anesthesia.   I don't have kids and am 46. (I am not Jenn "Green Acres" Michigan, no farm, either!)  Overall I am in pretty good shape. I hadn't had other surgery (such as c-section) so I would say my surgery was straightforward. I had not had an issue with hot flashes or night sweats or other menopausal stuff because my level of estrogen was pretty low beforehand (thank you, Zoladex!). You are not supposed to lift more than 10lbs for a bit. take care  PS I work from home (writing at computer). I had to get back to a project--I had the surgery on a Weds. I rested from Weds to Sunday. I felt fine to get back to it. But if you can take the time to rest, do it, note what Leah and Jenn said about doing too much too soon.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 06:17PM EnglishMajor wrote: Hi Patti I'm not an HR person, but I agree--you are not obligated to discuss your illness. But you will probably have to address the gap in your work history...it could be you wanted to spend more time with your kids, as well as deal with the chemo. (I would just make it clear that you didnt' quite your last job on a whim and that you weren't fired.) It sounds like you like to keep busy, which is a rare employee quality in my experience, so I would stress that. I talked to one HR expert who liked to say that most people CAN do the job they were hired to do, the real question is WILL they? You can say that you are known for your postive attitude in face of adversity.   Can you think of a couple specific examples from your last job that demonstrated your abitlity to deal with kids/parents/teachers/stress?  For example, maybe you had to deal with a rude parent or misbehaving kid. What was your solution?

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2013 09:33AM EnglishMajor wrote: Without knowing her, it's hard to say. It could be that managament has offered but she prefers the status quo. It can be really difficult. I'm now in a different job. Previously I was the boss, I had two subordinates. When I was dx'd three years ago, I was kind of in and out of the office seemingly for a month. It was originally thought I would be having surgery and or chemo. (I was ultimately found to have a low volume of bone mets and put on Tamoxifen.) My senior subordinate had to "take over." I returned about a month later and it was so hard to re-establish our roles. My subordinate treated me like a ghost. I used to call meetings and lead them. Now I wasn't even being invited. In fairness, it was hard on my colleague. She had to do my job (and it's not like she was compensated for doing it). On the other hand, I think she enjoyed the power (such as it was). My head was not really in my job for months. I was just trying to get my mind around everything. Asserting myself at work wasn't a top priority...On one level, it bothered me (or my ego) that I had been usurped, on the other hand, I was just going thru the motions at work. It was hard to explain why I wasn't having chemo or surgery. I think my subordinate feared I would suddenly be back to my rounds of tests or possibly hospital stays and she had to protect herself, too. So who knows....it could be that Robin herself insists on "doing it all."

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 02:05PM EnglishMajor wrote: I was reading online about a woman with a similar dx as me (bone mets ER/PR+ HER2-). She is doing the standard treatments (anihormonals, I think tamoxifen) plus "supplementing" with periodic treatment at a (to my mind) dubious "clinic" in the Southwest. She is on SSDI which typically does not cover alternative tx. So she has set up fundraisers etc. to come up with the $30k at the clinic, things like Vitamin C IVs, etc.  Her healh is generally good, which she ascribes to the "clinic" as she now puts forth more fund raising bulletins for another visit. During her first stay at the clinic, she met six other patients, with various cancers, one with MBC. All have since died. This might make me think I could do something better with $30k. But the rationale is "they waited too long" to go to this place. A simple Google search revealed her doctor has run afoul of the state board on several occasions. One of the drugs he touted to her has all been called quackery. And yet, this woman handed her medical records to this guy and wrote down everything he said, as tho he were some great guru. (He did advise her to take the hormonal tx.) It was like she had an audience with the Mighty Oz... I think people believe what they want to, even in the face of massive evidence to the contrary....

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 09:27PM EnglishMajor wrote: Hi Molly I presented with mets and have been stable on Tamoxifen. With Stage IV, you get the least toxic option first. If your sister's cancer were immediately life threatening or agressive, she would have to start with chemo. Sometimes people equate side effects with a drug's effectiveness. Hormonal (ie tamoxifen) therapy is just effective as chemo, but it does take longer to work. If your sister need fast action, she would have chemo right away. With Stage IV, the goal is control. After awhile, a given treatment will stop working and it on to the next one. Women with ER/PR+ HER2-  generally have a wider range of drugs to work with.  In terms of drains, size would come into  play. A larger (more endowed) woman generally would  likely have more  drains.  I will send you a PM.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2012 06:25PM EnglishMajor wrote:  Things others have said that have stuck with me: Roz Kleban runs support groups for people with MBC in NYC. She said MBC is like"having a radio in your head that's on at all times distracting you from life. And you can't turn the radio off, but you can turn the volume down." The late Susan Davis, a tireless volunteer with the MBCN, said it best. Susan lived with mets for almost a dozen years. Although she endured progressively more grueling treatments, she said ultimately even the harshest side effects weren't as difficult as the mental fight. "I live in a constant state of hopeful dread," she wrote. "I am hopeful I will be stable. I dread that my next test will show I am not." "Another thing you get as a cancer patient is a lot of football-coach patter. 'You can beat this; you can win; you're strong; you're tough; get psyched.' I suspect that cancer doesn't give a rat's ass whether you have a positive mental attitude. It just sits in there multiplying away, whether you are admirably stoic or weeping and wailing. The only reason to have a positive mental attitude is that it makes life better. It doesn't cure cancer." --Molly Ivins Read more: http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,201917,00.html#ixzz23v4ay7i6

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2012 10:42PM EnglishMajor wrote: ER+ is generally good it means she can try milder options (antiestrogen) like Femara. Assume the radiation was for pain, hopefully that helped.  ER/PR+ w/HER2NEU+ often has an indolent course. If your mom's cancer was aggressive she would likely have to do chemo first.  If your mom's cancer was limited to her breast, she would get local treastment (possibly surgery, chemo and radiation). Becasue it has spread beyond the breast, it must be treated systemically (whole body). Even she had a mastectomy, the cancer would still be in her bones. Can't remove bones, so hence no surgery. Surgery isn't standard of care for someone with Stage IV, but in some cases there is thought to be some benefit. Each case is considered individually--it might not make sense for your mom to have surgery.    With metastatic breast cancer you try one thing and generally are scanned every 3-4 months. When it stops working you move onto the next drug. Some people can get years out of antihormonals, which is awesome.  It is "good" that your mom has estrogen receptive (ER/PR+) cancer in that there are many antihormonal options for it.   As my doctor told me, no one dies of bone mets. (Which is not to say they aren't painful or won't spread. But once cancer spreads outside the bones, that is a different kettle of fish.) We are all different---I am 46 & have a small volume of bone mets but overall am in good health. If your mom has other health issues, that is something else that must be considered. Terri is correct that most people with bone mets have a bisphosphonate (bone booster infusion of Zometa or Xgeva). I did not start with right away tho but it is something to ask about. Generally your teeth have to be in good shape b/4 you can start on Zometa or Xgeva. Vitamin D  is important for bone health, typically oncologists will check this level when they do blood tests (not every time, just perodically).

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2013 10:44PM EnglishMajor wrote: here are some suggestions.... BreastCancer.org (this board, etc) https://secure3.convio.net/bco/site/SPageServer?pagename=Donate_Now Your donation will help Breastcancer.org reach millions of people around the world with medical information and community support when they need it most. As most know I volunteer with the Metastatic Breast Cancer Network MBCN is a national, independent, nonprofit, patient advocacy group dedicated to the unique concerns of the women and men living with metastatic breast cancer. MBCN was founded in 2004 by Jane Soyer and Nina Schulman. When diagnosed with advanced breast cancer, they experienced feelings of isolation from the very groups established to provide support. They felt the stigma of being a “failure” in the breast cancer community. Their belief that cancer cannot be viewed as a disease from which one is either a “survivor” or to which one has succumbed, fueled their desire to advocate for change. Metavivor champions research.... . An all volunteer, non-profit organization, METAvivor was founded and is run largely by persons with MBC. Established in 2007 as a local (Annapolis MD) support program, the group began a fundraising campaign in 2008, became a non-profit organization in 2009, began awarding its own annual MBC research grants in 2010 and in 2011 began advocating 30% for 30%

Take care Arranging The Shiva House The physical set-up of the shiva house includes the following: Memorial Candle - A person's soul is compared to a flame, since each person brings light into the world. And just as one can take from a flame to light more candles without diminishing the original flame, so too a person can give of him/herself, touching many lives, without ever being diminished. The wick and the flame are also compared to the body and soul, and the strong bond between them. And just as a soul always strives upward for what is good and right, so too a flame burns toward the heavens. Thus a memorial candle is lit in the shiva house and remains burning publicly 24 hours per day throughout the entire week. When you look at the candle, remember that your loved one's soul is eternal. This thought can help bring light into the darkness in which you are now immersed.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 12:10AM - edited Feb 5, 2012 12:12AM by EnglishMajor Are you thinking of a PET or an MRI? For the PET, you are feet first and you graduallly inch forward, like groceries on a conveyor-like table. So it is "open" until the last bit.  With PETs you may be able to wear your clothes; for MRIs you will likely have to wear a gown (and no metal due to magnet).   For the PET, you would like get a tracer injection and then sit in a dark/quiet room to let it work thru you.   MRIs are more enclosed, tho some facilities offer open ones. For the MRI, consider asking your doctor for antianxiety medicine beforehandl

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2010 01:15AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:20AM by EnglishMajor Hi Cookie I would suggest giving the Cancer Legal Resource Center a call. They are affiliated with Loyola (Los Angeles) and their services are free. They can advise of you of your rights under the ADA . Even if you think this doesn't apply to you, I would still give them a call--there might be something you didn't know. Or they may have tips. And you have nothing to lose. See: www.disabilityrightslegalcenter.org The Cancer Legal Resource Center (CLRC) is a national, joint program of the Disability Rights Legal Center and Loyola Law School Los Angeles. The CLRC provides free information and resources on cancer-related legal issues to cancer survivors, caregivers, health care professionals, employers, and others coping with cancer. A cancer diagnosis may carry with it a variety of legal issues, including insurance coverage, employment and taking time off work, access to health care and government benefits, and estate planning. The CLRC has a national, toll-free Telephone Assistance Line (866-THE-CLRC) where callers can receive free and confidential information about relevant laws and resources for their particular situation. Members of the CLRC's Professional Panel of attorneys, insurance agents, and accountants can provide more in-depth information and counsel to CLRC callers. Also: www.cancerandcareers.org/emplo...  The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA): * Covers employers with 15 or more employees * Includes cancer in its definition of "disability" * Prohibits employers from discriminating against a person with cancer or with a history of cancer * Requires "reasonable workplace accommodation" of people with cancer * Covers a "qualified" person, defined as one who has the experience and training to be able to "perform the essential functions" of the job. * Requires an employer to provide the same compensation and benefits to someone with cancer as it would provides to an employee without cancer. * Will be most useful for a person with cancer who is going through treatment and needs an accommodation like working at home. * Covers an employee with cancer only if she decides to disclose that she has cancer. Protects caregivers as well as people with cancer. Here are some other helpful resources about the ADA: U.S. Department of Justice (http://www.usdoj.gov/crt/ada/business.htm) Cancercare (http://cancercare.org/managing/workplace/employer/law.asp) American Cancer Society(http://www.cancer.org/docroot/MIT/mit_3_1_2.asp)

You can see her on youtube ' FDA Blocks Life -Saving Cancer Drug ", Part 4. ( google the petition by the same title, sign and pass on ). While there , take a look at peter in Part 3. hes doing great on the pertuzumab/t dm-1/taxol trial. Where evryone gets t dm-1 . The next best trial is Theresa, becuase 2 out of 3 get t dm-1. The other trials are 50/50 . If your cancer strongly overexpresses her 2, t dm-1 seems to work better. My wifes FISH Scale measurement of her2 was a 6.0, anything over 3.0 is considered significant. There is a s/e of platelet drops. my wifes did, and she took a dose reduction from 3.6 to 3.0. Probably should have done it sooner . Her plats barely stabilized in time to stay in the Study. She got 7 doses at 3.6, now has had 11 at 3.0. Hinsight , maybe 4 -5 doses at 3.6 then dropping to 3.0. We have not been afraid to speak up, to both Gen. top brass, our Partners Health care Insurers, FDA, Congress. pressure put on us to drop to the lowest dose , 2.4 , by Gen. top brass, even by our own doc, who we love, she had never used it, was nervous , . We refused , its Lorraines life, and we want the strongest dose , until its approved, becuase of the rules. We wrer right ! with 3.0 every 3 weeks, plats slowly stabilized at 65,000 -80,000, slowly rising . And most importantly , the cancer shrunk away. No sign of it on CT's since November ! Another consequence of This FDAs' bureaucratic, political , denial of approval , is that pts continue to be forced into trials with rigid dosing rules ( once you reduce you cant go back up ), and timing ( more than 6 weeks betw. doses, and you may get dropped ). So the s/e of platelet drop is made worse by This FDA ! I know this may sound scary, but want people to be informed. It is a great , breakthrough Drug for metastatic her2 . !! QOL is awesome ! Good luck !

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 04:58PM EnglishMajor wrote: Musa Mayer is a good, authorative source on mets. She writes: Last night, Genentech announced that T-DM1 has shown a statistically significant (but unspecified) increase in the length of time prior to disease progression (PFS) in their Phase III EMILIA trial, when compared with lapatinib (Tykerb) plus capecitabine (Xeloda) in HER2+ MBC patients whose disease has progressed on Herceptin plus Taxol. T-DM1, or as the company is now calling it, Trastuzumab Emtansine, is an antibody-drug conjugate, made by linking Herceptin with a potent chemotherapy drug too toxic to use intravenously, in such a way that it is released only within the HER2+ cancer cells targeted by the Herceptin. This decreases the toxicity of the chemotherapy for patients. There are no numbers indicating what the increase in median PFS actually is in this press release, and we do not yet know if T-DM1 helps patients live any longer, known as overall survival (OS). The full results will be presented at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) annual meeting in early June, and the full results will be submitted to FDA for approval. As you may recall, FDA rejected Genentech's application for approval for T-DM1 a couple of years ago based on the results of a single-arm study in late stage HER2+ MBC, since they require comparative data, even though these results looked very promising. However, several factors argue that the application for approval will be successful this time--in my opinion. >First, Tykerb has been shown to be inferior when compared directly with Herceptin. >Second, several studies have demonstrated that Herceptin continues to be effective after failure of initial treatment with Herceptin+Taxol, when combined with another chemotherapy agent. >Third, measured toxicities will almost certainly be significantly less with T-DM1 when compared with Tykerb+Xeloda, which has diarrhea as an overlapping toxicity with both drugs, and also causes rash (Tykerb) and hand-foot syndrome (Xeloda) in a high proportion of patients. >And fourth, in considering drug approvals, FDA considers a decrease in toxicity to be a real clinical benefit, although short periods of PFS has been controversial as an outcome (endpoint), as we saw with Avastin. When considering drugs for approval, FDA always weighs safety (toxicities) against efficacy. As an avid follower of the FDA approval process, I believe that if the PFS turns out to be more than a month or two in EMILIA, and if the toxicities are much less, that T-DM1 will win approval this time. So, all in all, good news! Here is the press release: http://www.gene.com/gene/news/press-releases/display.do?method=detail&id=13887 Musa  http://www.bcmets.org/articles/148924

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 03:11AM EnglishMajor wrote: Many tests and analyses will be done over several weeks to figure out your diagnosis. The most critical test results-for your treatment and your long-term health-will tell you and your doctor: * whether the cancer is non-invasive or invasive * whether lymph nodes are involved and if so, how many? The single mos. Invasive cancer has spread outside the mt important factor in the personality of any breast cancer is whether it is non-invasive ("in situ," which means "in the same place") or invasive mmilk duct or milk-making glands and has grown into normal tissue inside the breast. Whether your cancer is non-invasive or invasive will determine your treatment choices and how you might respond to the treatments you receive. Non-invasive (or "in situ") cancers confine themselves to the ducts or lobules and do not spread to the surrounding tissues in the breast or other parts of the body. They can, however, develop into or raise your risk for a more serious, invasive cancer. Invasive (or infiltrating) cancers have started to break through normal breast tissue barriers and invade surrounding areas. Much more serious than non-invasive cancers, invasive cancers can spread cancer to other parts of the body through the bloodstream and lymphatic system.

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2013 08:48PM EnglishMajor wrote: Hi Barb Zometa can be associated with osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ). In ONJ, bone is exposed. temporomandibular joint (TMJ) acts like a sliding hinge, connecting your jawbone to your skull. TMJ disorders can cause pain in your jaw joint and in the muscles that control jaw movement. TMJ is often associated with teeth grinding. It may not be relasted to taking Zometa. I'd ask the dentist to clarify.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2012 07:16PM EnglishMajor wrote: Without knowing what else might be going on with your MIL this is just speculation, but here goes... Here is one overview of prognosis in advanced cancer. Remember this is pretty general: "How long do I have, Doc? is among the most common questions asked by cancer patients...Although prognostication is not an exact science, there are data to help clinicians provide useful information to patients and families: http://www.eperc.mcw.edu/EPERC/FastFactsIndex/ff_013.htm It sound like your MIL is doing pretty well--how you are feeling is a key diagnostic sign. If she is doing well and feeling well that is great. No one can say when how or when things might change. Given that she has had a good response so far, that's a good thing. To my mind, the lung mets are more concerning than the bone mets. Bone mets can be painful but as my doctor says "No one dies of bone mets." When cancer spreads to liver, lung or brain, that is a different kettle of fish, tho you will find people with all varieties of mets on this board doing pretty well.  Your MIL's cancer is ER/PR+ and HER2- which is "good" in that she has many antihormonal treatments (like the one she is on) that she can do before doing chemo.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 09:07AM EnglishMajor wrote: I think it was probably said with the best of intentions. From my limited HR knowledge, this is likely treading on some shaky ground. Cancer is covered under the ADA and FMLA. If I were the employer, I would be wary of any comment that might be misconstrued. On a personal level, I can relate somewhat. The phrasing of the above suggests an unwritten sentiment: We expect your disease to inconvenience us.  Thanks for ensuring it doesn't.  When I was first diagnosed, I had to take two weeks off for tests etc.  Before the telltale bone scan (Do Not Pass Go, Do Not Collect $200, Go Directly to Stage IV Jail), I was preparing for a mastectomy. Well, didn't have one and went back to work. My coworker referred to me as being on medical leave. I informed her that if I WAS on leave, I would have told her and the HR dept in writing.  What was worse, she was acting like I had one foot in the grave and the other on a banna peel. In retrospect, I understand her reaction--how would she know what was going on with me (I barely did). But man, was I pissed off. Probably because "medical leave" suggested a helplessness or hospital stay that just wasn't there.  In fairness, her misstatement of my absence was  a minor thing but it probably unleashed a lot of anger about related issues.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 02:47PM EnglishMajor wrote:  FYI, Darby Steadman went from DCIS to Stage IV For help with clincal trial expenses check out Driving Miss Darby St. Petersburg, Florida - 40-year-old Darby Steadman has a moving message about the bond between mothers and daughters. An experience with her own mother, 64-year-old Pam Bissett, gave her the idea to start a foundation to help women with breast cancer. Steadman is battling stage stage four cancer and says, "I will never be in remission. My cancer will never go away. I will never be cancer free." But, despite that, Steadman, who was born and raised in Tampa, says she's actually very lucky. "It means that time is precious. It's a beautiful gift that I am just blessed each and every day that I get to see my family and wake up my children and get them off to school." Steadman was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2004. She had a bilateral mastectomy and thought the cancer was gone. She says, "My doctor had indicated that I had a less than one percent chance of it coming back or a reoccurrence. So, in 2007, I was very surprised to find out that my cancer had come back." The cancer is now attacking her vertebra, bones and her lymph nodes. Despite that, she and her friends started a foundation to help advance clinical research for breast cancer and help patients that are enrolled in clinical trials. Steadman was enrolled in an intense clinical trial at Johns Hopkins for eight months and says, "We have funded this vaccine trial that Doctor Leisha Emens has created at Johns Hopkins. We've given them $25,000." Click here to read more about the clinical trial being conducted at the Johns Hopkins Kimmel Cancer Center. The foundation's goal is to also help offset some of the patient's expenses when taking part in clinical trials. The name of the foundation is Driving Miss Darby. Steadman explains how it works. "They can call us and say, 'Hey, can you pick me up from the airport?' and I'm the driver. I say, 'Of course I can, let me come and get you.' I'll try to take them to breakfast and things like that, but really what we want to do is help offset that financial burden." Steadman says plane tickets, hotel rooms, cab fare and food can be expensive when patients are traveling to the site of the clinical trial each week for months. She says she got the idea for the foundation from when her mother would drive her to her appointments. Bissett, meanwhile, says she understands how critical clinical trials are not only for her daughter but for other women too. Bissett is also a breast cancer survivor. "Without the trials, there's no new medicine coming out. These ladies give up a lot to go through a trial. They don't have a whole lot of time."

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 05:59PM EnglishMajor wrote: Flatsy McNasty here. I have had the opposite reaction. Not tears perse but something I ordinarily would shrug off has provoked outbursts that are even surprising to me while they are happening. It's like part of me is getting all riled up with someone about some dumb thing and part of me is going, "Hey, where did THAT come from?" Could be the tamoxfen, I dunno. On the positive side, being irritable could signify low levels of estrogen, a good thing with hormonal tx. Or it could just mean I am a crankypants.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2013 03:16PM EnglishMajor wrote: I don't have pleurx catheter so don't know about that.  I couldn't have reconstruction. I was stopped a couple of times when going thru the back scattter machines (the things that look like the a star trek transporter/phone booth). I'm guess it's because I'm not symmetrical--one side does not match the other as I cuold not have reconstruction after my unilateral bmx. After that, if I have had to go thru those machines, I've said something to the security person before stepping into the scanner. I have said something like "I have breast cancer and I don't have a left breast." One time they had me do the "manual" pat down off to the side with a female agent. The other times they had me go thru machine. I think I was told to wait and then the security person told me to go on thru. I don't always say something--I haven't had issues with the old type machines--but I feel much better kind of taking the power upfront---Telling the sercurity agent vs. waiting for some kind of interrogation. I don't think they would remove a bandage--especially if you have documentation.
